headline: Good company, long history, struggles to appeal to new generation
pros:
As a client, Ameriprise is a great place to trust with your money. Safe. Conservative. Even keeled. 

As an advisor, great place to serve clients. Good technology. Good reputation. Good resources. 

As a corporate employee, great place to work if you're close to retirement. Pays ok. Benefits decent.
cons:
Does not move at the pace of change. Sometimes this is on purpose. 

Very hierarchical. No one likes to make decisions because there's a fear of the person above them. 

So risk adverse employees are often handcuffed into doing things the way they've always been done.

May not fully understand the definition of flexibility.

headline: Not the best or worst company to work for
pros:
The company believes in yearly raises based on performance.
They have a matched 401(k) up to 5% and other normal benefits.
There is some room for upwards mobility.
cons:
Their raises are paltry and are not up for negotiation. They believe you should just be happy with what is offered. 
They want the absolute most from you, despite there not being an incentive for it.
They will sabotage upwards mobility if they think it will harm their current team, yet claim they have your back in times of promotions. 
They hire for x, y and z, but will not pay you for the ridiculous amount of extra work piled on after the first few weeks.

headline: Executives don't care about their employees well-being
pros: My co-workers are about it

Executive management does not care about their employees and treat them like children. Forced to come in to the office during a pandemic with crime at an all time high in MPLS. They are so out of touch with their own employees' struggles.

Pay is not adequate. Received $1k raise beginning of 2021 even though they go on and on about how well the business is doing. 

Benefits are mediocre for a large company like this. 

Micromanaging forced from the top. Tracking time in office of their best employees even though they are salary.

Preach innovation and change when they are a very old-school and do not want to change their ways. The world is changing! Get on board or get left behind.

headline: Leadership doesn't listen
pros: There's some flexibility, depending on the job itself.
cons:
Corporate leadership is not transparent and it feels there is a hidden agenda. There appears to not be an actual strategy as it's never been communicated. Leaders have lied to their teams, doing a complete 180, and then behaving as though it's not a big deal. 

Everything I'm seeing tells me leadership has an old world mentality. I see nothing that indicates they actually support "innovation" though they throw this word around a ton.

Pay is low if you've been with the company forever (as-is the situation with most companies), and they are incredibly resistant to review and adjust. The "equity adjustment" they claim can be done once a year is far below what would actually bring someone to where they need to be. 

Promotions happen subjectively and there's no hiding the discriminatory behavior. They just don't care, even when the entire team communicates their concerns in fairly strong terms. And yes, even up to the VP level - they just ignore everyone and act as though nothing needs to be addressed. There is no consideration for one's skills or contributions. 

They also lie, stating that a role can't be created without significant time needed to work with HR to ensure they create a job description, but then turn around and promote someone into a role that doesn't exist. And when asked about it, they pretend that it's not a big deal, nor provide further direction explaining how to achieve a promotion.

The corporate value of "integrity always" feels like empty words to many employees because leadership actions don't always reflect this.

The company has also battled tooth and nail against allowing employees to work remotely. Leadership is insanely resistant to change. Even at a meeting with executives, they misappropriated pictures of employees by using them in a "return to office" montage, showing these people in the office. It was implied these people endorsed coming back to the office - completely wrong. These people weren't told the pictures would be used in this way. Very shady which is aligned with a lot of what I've seen in leadership over the last couple of years.

The problem I'm seeing here is that all companies seem to keep the bar low so they can act like they're great when they are slightly better than most other companies. They need to hold themselves to a much better standard.

headline: Work and responsibilities not as promised in AWM Tech India team
pros:
Good company, great learning resources.
Cheerful Colleagues.
cons:
Quality of work not very helpful to grow and establish career in tech.

No work life balance due to odd shift timings.
Few senior members in the team expect flattery in order to even be considered an active team member. 

Onshore heads  persecute and force you to work on things (BPO kind of voice process work and excel) that are not necessary and trivial even at the cost of your time, experience and career. They  create work pressure for such things and won't assign projects as they prioritize this over what you have been actually hired for and the skills you have , thereby denying you  to learn and grow in the role that you desired to work on while getting hired.

Slow growth.  

Worked there for almost a year and was not even assigned  a project, wasted all my time in call support which took me no where, while I was supposed to work in development, left at the right time before becoming irrelevant to the tech industry.

Always reassure your work and responsibilities if joining AWM Tech team, never stay even for a month if you are not given the work that you are supposed to get as they will never care to even consider to make things better even if you spend years together there.

The above comments were for some particular projects  handled by some highly ignorant  people of AWM Tech India team,  but I suppose other teams and they company is much better than this.

headline: Some Cons Some Pros
pros:
- There is a proper process to do each and every thing. In case you stuck at a point then there is proper hierarchy to help you out.
- When you join the company, then they make you fully comfortable and help on each and every step.
- Best part about working here in Analytics department is US Business partners, they explain the work in detailed manner and set the realistic expectations
- This company takes there ratings seriously and whatever we right in our appraisal forms is evaluated and validated properly
- Good learning opportunities 
- Analytics and Technology are treated as elite here
- Resolving any tech issues or hr issues. Turn around time is very low
cons:
- Long Term deferred bonus is biggest deception, this bonus is only beneficial if you are retiring from this company only, as full benefit of this bonus can be redeemed from 3rd year onwards. So basically we get very low bonus in first year and then below average bonus in 2nd year and decent (not so high) on completing 3rd year in the firm. The bonus that we are going to get from third year on a default rating is similar to the bonus that we get first year onwards in many firms
- Micro management had increased a lot during lockdown, earlier it was good, now there is tracker for each and every thing
- There are lots of engagement activities and sometimes they push us to attend or participate in those, even if we have no capacity 
- Getting good rating in the organization, you have to participate/organize engagement activities, sometimes this also plays important role in getting promotions timely
- Promotions are not easy here, you have to do lot to get promoted apart from work, if you really want the promotion, then you have to say yes to every kind of work, either maintaining the excel tracker or organizing meetings, organizing events , participating in the events, being funny in the meetings, doing laundry work for your supervisor.
- No goodies on festivals, you can get that by participating in the activities
- As normal shift timing is from 2pm to 10:30pm, you will be super busy after 7 pm
- Punch In Punch out system of 8 hour while in the office, finger print basis.

- Taking leave is a long process in some projects: 
Six step process to take leave:
1) Take alignment from US business partners
2) Inform India leaders about leave, get a green light from them, if it is okay to take the leave or not according to team capacity
3) Drop a calendar invite to all
4) Apply leaves on the portal
5) Get approval on planned time off
6) Update the excel tracker

headline: Company Only Focus is Funneling Money to Executives
pros: Good work and life balance
cons:
Try googling "ameriprise employee 401k lawsuit" and that will tell you all you need to know about how this company treats their employees. A company whose business is to manage people's lifesavings tried to cheat their own employees on their life savings to marginally pad the pockets of the executive leadership team. They constantly look for ways to nickel and dime their employees so they can marginally increase executive compensation. 

Management at all levels boast that they pay less than all of their competitors. If you ask to be paid even close to what Ameriprise themselves say is the competitive pay for your position, they will not only decline, but will ridicule you for asking. The CEO was named the most overpaid CEO in the world by Business Journal, and had his compensation voted down by shareholders in non-binding votes. When Ameriprise received the largest corporate tax cut in US history, they froze their employee pension plan, added a surcharge to the health insurance plan for employees' family members, and then instituted $10 billion in share buybacks to enrich the executive leadership team. 

All of my accomplishments were kept secret from upper management. Upper management is completely unaware of the risks associated with certain lines of business and which employees are mitigating those risks. Lower management will not share that an employee saved the company from multiple billion dollar disasters because it would make them look bad that there is even that risk, which results in that employee never being rewarded or recognized for extraordinary company-saving accomplishments. Middle-management is lazy, and in many cases, completely useless. Most are Ameriprise lifers who have no idea how typical businesses are managed. Some managers don't have the basic knowledge of what their employees do to be able to give relevant performance reviews. Regardless of performance, talent, or skills, it's easy to get stuck in a job that Ameriprise will want to keep you trapped in the rest of your life.

Even on my way out, the company tried to short me on my accrued vacation payout, thinking I wouldn't notice.

- Advisor used his own family to spy on staff
- Advisor used new AFAs to keep hourly logs of salaried employees
- Advisor made several claims about "women empowerment" and the importance of hiring women in "advisor roles", but has only hired men and fired women since my employment began 4 years ago.

headline: Toxic corporate culture led by a CEO that lives in a separate state from where the companies is headquartered
pros: Benefits are decent, Fortune 200 company
cons: The company is run from NY. Even though the headquarters employees are all based in Minneapolis. The CEO is out of touch with the rank and file employees. Compensation for positions is often lower than industry standards. The culture is fake, gossipy and is based on clicks. Because of rule by clicks, gossip and the NY leadership’s belief all employees work on a sales desk like Wolf of Wall Street, leadership resists WFH hybrids. Leadership seems to have an aphasia on how to actually show employee appreciation or provide positive reinforcement. Therefore, days are spent trying to stay on the right side of clicks and avoid being gossip fodder. Therefore, you are exhausted by playing the part to stay on the right side of the gossip and clicks.

headline: A politician's paradise
pros:
Work life balance is the only good thing about this company. You may be able to leave office at 5, and enjoy your evening. Occasionally you may need to work in the evening, but that's acceptable.

Nothing else is Pro here.
cons:
Ameriprise is one of the most slow moving company in twin cities. Frequent red tapes, process paralysis, slows down any attempted progress and technological enhancements. Senior leadership is most interested to keep the lights on, any architectural advancement is either shot down by other “high priority” items (read cost savings), or uncooperative delivery teams. Since architecture team depends on delivery team most, to keep the ball rolling, 99% of the time architecture teams don’t have any impact due to uncooperative, stubborn nature of delivery teams.

Then comes the politics. Ameriprise runs on chain of buttering of immediate leaders, instead of taking right decisions, junior leaders are most interested in making their superior happy. Unless the superior had directed, nothing (and I mean absolutely nothing) is heard from a junior employee. Here people don’t have respect for anyone who has more technical knowledge, rather people are busy in office politics. Mid level leaders don’t have any decency or respect for junior employees, they are often treated as second grade citizen. You will prosper, if you can play good politics, don’t need any technical knowledge. Junior employees are not recognized for their good work, or motivate them.

I don’t even want to mention the below par compensation, compared to other companies in twin cities. The environment in Ameriprise is so toxic and cut throat, only in few months, you will lose your appetite to enjoy your work and only be frustrated, unmotivated with the politics around you.

cons:
Ameriprise says it cares about employees, but the decisions they make are obviously meant to benefit nobody but shareholders.
Compensation structure was recently changed, and not for the better.
Highly risk-averse, which tends to hamstring innovation.
Not very nimble; so much process, and everyone has to review everything all the time.
Ameriprise is not known for blazing new trails; they'll wait and see what competition does before making big decisions.
Facilities are becoming outdated.
Always puts the needs of the business and shareholders ahead of the needs of employees. You are a number.
Tolerates bad behavior in middle management.

headline: Politics, Nepotism, Mediocrity, Incompetence...These are a few words to describe this organization
pros:
There is a good sense of work/life balance here, but for me that came because the pace of work was very slow and quite frankly things were simple. When you are surrounded by peers and leaders that strive to be in the bottom percentile, there is seldom a fire to get much done. 

The benefits were decent, but year after year they were eroding away.
cons:
I could write pages about this place, but my headline says it all. Politics, nepotism, mediocrity and incompetence are self-explanatory. 

I have never worked at a place that tolerates and even serves the lowest common denominator on a team. Ameriprise brags about tenure, but that is nothing to be proud of when you employ staff that haven't learned anything new since the 90's. Middle management is full of people who have no clue what being a leader is, nor do they have a clue how to their job, their employees job, let alone innovate anything. Many of the managers I had to deal with seemed to be intimidated by those perceived to be below them if they had ideas and skillsets that far surpassed theirs. 

Other issues:

Salary was not comparable to the market
Pay raises were either non-existent or mediocre
No real training opportunities
No growth opportunities (this ties into the political/nepotism issues)
Seemingly no rewards for working harder or taking on extra responsibilities

headline: Perception more important than performance. Good company if you have no dreams and want to settle.
pros: Analytics team. Great company if you want to settle. Peaceful. Great work life balance. No doubt. Generally the people are good.
cons:
BEWARE OF THE LTDP (Long term deferred Bonus). It's a trick used at Ameriprise. Make sure you check what monthly income you will be getting. This LTDB is paid one-third every year. Whenever you leave, there will be a huge component you wont get. PEOPLE HAVE ALWASY BEEN DISSATISFIED AFTER JOINING THE COMPANY CZ THEY DIDN'T UNDERSTAND LTDB. BE cautious. My manager didn't believe in women, and made a perception which no way could be changed.
Apart from work life balance and transportation benefits, the company pays very low importance to employee satisfaction. The entire leadership is cheap, they wont let money out easily. They'll not spend on you easily, and whatever they'll do, they'll mention again and again in townhall. Half of you day would go in meetings (which might be marked optional but will be mandatory).
Data Science Analytics works on some pillars like statistics and visualisation tools. If stats is your thing, forget you'll be recognised at all, whatever impact you make, or whatever hard work you do. If you don't do anything, just make a visualisation tool and you'll be appreciated. Meaning, if your business partners wont let you do flashy stuff ( generally they wont), forget being thanked for your job even. Salary increment wont be good unless you resign. Ratings will be decided by just one person who leads Analytics, although he mostly doesn't know what is being done in the projects. Its all how well you look to him.
So, if you want to settle and can buttter up, go ahead. Learning would be almost flat.

headline: Work Life Balance is all Work no Life
pros: Ameriprise is a good firm, and most groups treat their employees with respect and dignity (not RCS).
cons:
All Work - No Life Approach - Internal Audit (aka RCS / Risk Control Services) prides itself as an old fashion management style. You are lucky to have a job and there is no room for hurt feelings or people that don’t “want to work”. They are looking for “big 4 types”; people that “want to work” and will happily work long days and weekends (not to get ahead but to run with the pack, as everyone is required to put in long hours). If you want to work as if you are on the partner track, without any track or any example of anyone that advanced by following the program, this is the job for you. 
You are scheduled to work 42 hours a week, and if you need to get caught up or want to get ahead, you will do it after you have worked the scheduled 42 hours. Take a 2 week vacation and you will have to make up the 4 hours you missed when you return. The 42 hours is not usually an issue because most people are working well over 50 hours per week year-round (more during busy season). While there is paid sick time, if you are sick Wednesday, plan to work all day Saturday and Sunday to keep up on the time you missed while sick and the normal weekend time you would have to had to have worked. The audit plan is ridiculously aggressive. When assigned an audit, it is generally half the time you would reasonably assume it would take to complete. Through the planning process you can negotiate more time, but best-case scenario is generally 70% of what would be reasonable. You are left with a catch 22. You either report your hours that go over budget and “explain in detail why” or you underreport your hours and appear successful. 
If you have professional certifications plan on taking a lot of free CPE as the budget for paid CPE is small and spend is highly correlated to the people that charge the most hours to audits. 
Expect to get regular emails asking you why you charged 11 hours to do a task they believe should have taken 7. You will get these 6 weeks after you enter the time and be expected to provide details on why you took longer than the “expectation”. 
Three years is about the max you will see in tenure for people that are assigned audits (there are admins and special projects team members that have somewhat better success). There is no plan for career progression, no expects you will last more than a few years and you are treated like a contractor.

headline: Lack of integrity, Politics at it's worst, no job security
pros: They subsidize your medical insurance, cafeteria food, provide decent salaries, internal opportunities to move around if you can handle the politics, and some of the people are awesome.
cons: Upper-level Management politics. This company is a perfect example of what not to do in a company. You will not find more dysfunction and internal fighting/politics anywhere else. The only reason this company hasn't crashed is because they keep buying Advisors (EARs) and their book of business (BOB) and they pay more for them any other company. They have just as much money flowing out of the company (not just from current clients in outflows) as they are paying to bring in new clients. They have no retention program in place. They philosophy is that it's up to the Advisor, not the company. Whereas in the case of if you're trying to switch phone or cable providers they'll do almost anything in their power to keep you and throw all kinds of incentives at you to stay, this company simply helps you move your assets out the door. Not a great strategy in my opinion. The CFO, Walter, is a nutjob and you never know who you're going to get on any given day (depending on if he takes his meds or not). Unfortunately, he has no life or purpose outside of the company so he won't retire. He revels in creating chaos and internal drama/fighting. About 95% of the work I did was a pointless exercise and always a fire drill because some E-level Exec wanted to make a point so I had to make the numbers look however which way they wanted (lots of integrity in this place). It was not unusual for them to fire employees who had been loyal to the company their entire professional careers and replace them with someone younger and cheaper (even if it does end up costing more due to severance packages). They would constantly do cost-cutting exercises and outsource jobs to India (then move them back a few years later after it fails), but fail to invest in basic technology. For example, all of the financial reports were all created in Excel by combining a bunch of excel spreadsheets by someone in India who downloads the data from HFM, which would take days to do and obviously tons of room for human errors. Most companies would have these reports uploading to an online dashboard to have them available at a click of a button. Not here. They'd rather pay an employee $16K in India to do the report rather than invest in technology that could automate everything. I had worked in Finance for 10+ years at other companies and industries and couldn't believe how I had gone back in time when I joined this company. I seriously think I was getting dumber by staying there. My biggest dose of reality of this company culture was when I was doing a cost benefit analysis of a certain initiative. When I showed the results, my Leader (who is one position below the CFO), informed me the numbers weren't good enough to get approved and that I would have to go back and reconfigure them. In other words, throw out logic and just make the numbers support whatever this Management wanted to do. In its current trajectory, this company will be a fraction of what it is today in 10 years due to client outflows unless they merge with a different firm. They are only focused on the stock price (their bonuses) and not on their clients or employees, which is completely contradictory to the entire point of the industry - help people manage and increase their wealth.

headline: Stop Fooling around with people's Career
pros:
1.Good Food and cafeteria
2. Annual events
cons:
If you're joining here in as Network Engineer, please don't.. Your career will be destroyed working with L-0 tasks. 
1. No scope of Growth 
2. Incapable Leaders 
3. Politics at its peak
4. You won't ever get to work on what you were offfered during interview
5. False Commitments
6. No segregation of teams. You will have to do the work of NOC as well as have to meet SLA.  Or else bear the consequences from leaders. 
7. Worst quality work
8. Your voice will be heard but no Action will be taken ever
9. You will keep hearing the word Automation, but there is all Manual work that too at its best. 
10. Process keeps on changing every now and then to make sure you are irritated. 

I have more to say, but I think this is enough for you to take your decision.

headline: Great starting place, not LT
pros: They provide an astounding amount of support with sales training, service techniques, and opportunity at the Vegas AAC. They really are looking for your best foot forward and if you can give it, they'll let it pay off. Be curious and have a strong desire to improve. This job will not be a long-term position. Next it'll be either a lead CSA managing the business of each team practice or CRM where you'll be more of a financial advisor selling to clients an abundance of products. The Operations department is the backbone that you'll need.
cons: Downside is if you get in at a time of large onboarding groups you'll need to standout or get left idle. Participation is key and making an effort.

headline: Not a place to stay for long
pros: Some of the co-workers are nice. The events were fun.
cons: Pay was really bad for the level of work you do. No formal training; learn as you go. Some of the advisors are a complete mess with their heads all over the place and it's your job to figure everything out yourself, and it's your fault if they mess up or give you wrong information. The workload is very high and is always increasing to the point where you're maxed out and they still expect you to do more. Some advisors are demeaning and treat you like garbage, and then they turn around and come to you for advice because they have zero knowledge of anything outside of the starting point funds list; sometimes I wonder how they can give advice to their clients if they've never even looked at a chart or know anything about basic statistics. Favoritism and office politics rule; the guys walking around the office talking to their buddies and sneaking out early somehow get more praise than the guys at their desk working hard all day and doing their job. Made me sick to my stomach with how greed drives this place. Oh, and this company outsources most of the planning to India, so it seems misleading to the clients that think you're hard at work trying to customize their financial plan when in reality it's all being sent overseas and in return getting a prepackaged plan with a couple paragraphs switched around and their names inserted into it.

headline: Ok compensation, great exposure to leadership. Makes your work hard for every dollar.
pros: 5% match on 401k and get a cash balance pension after year obe and vests after 3 years.  Match is higher at competitive firms but not terrible.  Ok health insurance options
cons: Competition pays more but east opportunity to grow within company

headline: Sensational
pros: Ameriprise is a phenomenal company to work for.  Number ONE they are a reputable company. Additionally, there is a training module in place for everything on Advisor Compass. They continuously send (optional) webinars to help enhance your knowledge and someone is always willing to help. If you are unsure of how to complete a task, you can always call home office and someone is more than willing to help you finish the job or connect you to someone that can. Awesome company and I wish nothing but the best.
cons: None, Ameriprise has been an amazing start for me.

headline: Good Benefits but Awkward Atmosphere
pros: Ameriprise Financial offers the excellent benefits that come with working for a large, national corporation.
cons: Regardless of prior experience and certifications, a Client Service Associate is expected to just serve the advisors and not ask pertinent questions about the client details. If a supervising advisor makes false statements about a Service Associate on a performance review, the Associate may have no recourse, even after providing documentation to prove that the performance memorandum details are incorrect. Meanwhile, rather than being able to develop expertise in financial planning software and to participate in the planning process, an Associate is expected to use overseas resources to outsource the financial plan data entry and analysis.

cons: Inferior leadership. They wont allow you to stay and study or catch up after normal business hours. Thus making it difficult to gain deeper knowledge that's needed to do your job. Your best doesn't matter and is not good enough if you can't live up to the numbers on the board and you'll be punished if you don't meet those standards.  Gone are the days of coming to work, doing your job and going home.  They'll pay you well and give decent benefits, but prepare to sell your soul to the devil.  Highly stressful phone calls every day, some actually cry at least once a day.  Bravo ameriprise for that!

headline: Ameriprise Advisor Center (AAC) - Good luck!
pros:
Pay for licensing
5% 401k match (5 years until 100% vested)
9 managers in 6.5 years, majority of them were good people!
Benefits bench marked to be average / slightly below avg, but at least it's something!
cons:
Before you begin working in the Ameriprise Advisor Center (AAC), you have to ask yourself if you're comfortable working for a large and shrinking organization.
Over past 6.5yrs the number of people with "VP" in title has increased from 1 to 4. Number of "Directors" increased from 3 to 4. Number of financial advisors decreased from 350 down to around 50 today. Its approximately a 90% five year turnover rate. If you thrive under micro management, you'll do well here. 

Short term thinking is rampant. Decisions from VPs and Directors seem to be made with one of two things in mind: 1. This quarters bonus. 2. Getting quick results to pad their resume.

The AAC works primarily with C and D type clients that get turned in from the field practices. 95-98% of the time it's because: they are poor, they are old, all the money just got locked up in a REIT or annuity, they are difficult personalities to work with, they have a dying life insurance policy, or because they are already in the process of money assets away. So as an advisor in the AAC you operate on volume. Your job is to get blood from a stone. 8-15 appointments per day. 

AAC is unlike most financial service firms, in that they appear to be allergic to recurring revenue. Reality is that sales incentives over the past 5 yrs has lead to this.  Many advisors play 'hot patato' with the best clients (best in terms of revenue and NPS scores), this is because sales incentives only reward transaction business, not recurring revenue like financial plans or fee based asset management. So if all the money has been rolled over, they've already bought a plan and implemented, do your best to get that client OFF your calendar and onto some other person or you're not going have a good experience when it's bonus time.  

The AAC has never been more profitable, though you wouldn't know it talking to advisors since 95% of them see their income decrease around year three. This is because so much more of your time is spent working with clients you don't get any credit for helping. 

They enjoy a touch of nepotism. 2 out of the last 3 manager promotions went to people who are related to someone higher up in the department.  

Training has changed considerably over my time with the AAC. They used to train you to be an advisor in order to make recommendations to clients. Now they train you on how to read a script (aka call guide), and train you how to set an appointment for a specialist (who makes the actual recommendation on important decisions). 

Goals are set with no basis in reality. If your team loses half the advisors and support staff,\ they will tell you that you should feel lucky your targets are only going up 6% and not 15% the other teams. You can also count on annual changes to compensation, beginning every January. 

While they play plenty lip service to things improving and about caring about people, their actions have never supported this idea. You can no longer transfer the book you build to the field. Going to the field means starting all over. 

Worklife balance depends on your tenure. If you are their at 6:05 pm, you will likely just see tenured advisors trying to keep up with all their admin tasks. 45-55hrs per week is common, salaried of course. 
 
Culture in the AAC - most everyone that has been their longer than a year is jaded and cynical. At this point, you can only joke and laugh about how messed up things are. 

DO NOT FILL OUT THEIR EMPLOYEE SATISFACTION SURVEYS - the teams are small enough and they ask enough identifiable questions that they know who is who. They will try and coach you to take it and do the "n/a" for every question, so it doesn't hurt them and still they get their kudos for participation. If you take it and you answer truthfully, it will work against you.

Ameriprise is an okay company. Very conservative, they will never be innovators. Jimmy C as CEO is okay I guess,  but probably not worth 26mil per year.

headline: The Interview Process is a Nightmare
pros: Benefits include health insurance and paid time off.
cons:
The HR department is clueless and lazy. Hiring goes through the Minneapolis home office. I worked for an advisor in MD, and applied to a similar position when I moved to CO.  A "Sr. Recruiting Consultant, from Talent Acquisition" from Minneapolis emailed me on 8/13 to schedule a phone interview "in the next few days". I replied with my availability, and didn't hear back. After sending follow up emails on 8/17 and 8/28, the HR rep replied on 9/5: My apologies for the delay in getting back to you.  I have been out of the office since August 24th.  While I was out, it appears that an internal candidate has come forward to express an interest in the position so we have made the decision to offer this position to  that candidate.  I do greatly appreciate your interest in Ameriprise and this position and hope you will considering Ameriprise in the future. " 

Needless to say it was a frustrating experience. If possible, when looking for an admin or assistant position contact the desired office directly. Don't go through the corporate office.

headline: Strong company
pros: If you are viewed as a high producer/high potential employee, you will receive excellent executive coaching training and opportunities in the company and in industry.
cons: Leadership is a very high pressure, cut throat culture though does not boast of it publicly.  Work life balance is not encouraged at leadership levels, one has to devote to Ameriprise nearly completely.  Women are discouraged to speak of family or obligations outside the office - such discussion is viewed negatively particularly by women at higher levels in the company.  Almost a don’t ask don’t tell policy regarding other life roles one is also juggling - very stressful if one does not thrive in such an environment. Nothing wrong with that as long as you know what expectation you are signing up for when joining.  I left as I wanted to also openly devote to myself to my partner and family and have a full life that can be openly spoken of at work without negative view by my employer that a full life meant I was less dedicated or less worthy of advancement.

If you have an understanding leader, this will all be different. I was not lucky to receive one of those.

headline: The firm squeeze
pros: Ameriprise offer to its advisers an abundance of tools to do an effective job.  supported when needed.
cons: The cost structure at Ameriprise is tough.  There are fees for fees (so it seems).  To figure out exactly what the costs are for the use of its services are difficult to determine.  The culture is changing quickly and often.   Burdensome reporting requirements and overly rigid compliance methods stifle motivation and deter independent thinking.  Though recruits are told they are independent and their client belong to them if they leave (or they are lead to believe this lie).  The fact is that most do not read the contract they sign due to its complexity and length - nearly 260 pages of stuff only attorneys could seem to fully comprehend and this is a stretch.

headline: Micro Management & Politics at its peak
pros:
1. Transport Facility
2. Subsidized Food coupons
3. Cultural Events/Annual parties.
4. Average annual hikes.
5. Salary come 3-4 days before month end
cons:
1. Poor mid/senior management (They just hear, no action is taken)
2. Micro management at the peak level. 
3. Too much work pressure (extended shifts/weekends/odd shift timings/no allowance): 
4. No work life balance: If if you are sincere to your work and working extra hours/weekend for completing your project, lead/mgt will call multiple times in odd hours and will ask for status. 
5. No action taken by mgt even when there is employee crunch in the team. They will suck every bit from you and will ruin your life.specially in technical deptt.
6. leads from onshore think themselves as GOD. being technical, they like to drive whole process and team and create undue pressure to the teams.
7. Too much meetings. In case of issues, leads will glue you on the call until the issue gets fixed. Not expected such environment in such big organization.
8. Not suitable for female employees.
9. Too much politics, managers have their pawns in their team who will disclose your each and every information to them. 
10. Most managers are non technical and they don't understand what is going in terms of work, instead of understanding the issues and providing solution they will just create pressure on the team.
11. No WFH.
12. Very Complex pay structure (you would be very disappointed once you get take home salary, always you would loose one portion of your salary in case your resign)
13. No onsite opportunities.
14. You don't have much option to switch teams. (if your technology or project gets closed, you might have to look for opportunities outside the organization)

headline: Excellent choice to start with
pros:
I've joined Ameriprise six  months back. So, don't familiar much with the organization. But for someone looking to join ameriprise, here are few benefits i would like to mention:

1. Free Cab facility to every employee for all shifts
2. Long term deferred bonus, which starts appearing as a huge amount when you complete 3 years with the organization
3. Subsidised food (Lunch & Dinner). You can take it as an excellent benefit as many organizations have much higher rates and provides you almost nothing in return
4. Professional environment is helpful for employees pursuing their first job
cons: As of now, I've not seen any cons. May be after spending sometime in organization :)

headline: Technologies (15+ years)
pros: Great purpose, love my adviser and what he does - but if he decided to leave Ameriprise, I would follow him. Depending on department, can be good rewarding experience. Nice facility with good amenities and downtown if you enjoy that. Leaders with high IQ's. The workers are great, all good people trying to do a good job. Highly respected CEO.
cons:
Speaking to technology organization only as that is my experience - but comments could spread to other orgs. 

All new jobs ads start with "At Ameriprise it's about the people". This is a lie, technologies is absolutely one of the most toxic environments I had ever been in and "treating people with respect" couldn't be farther from it. Unfortunately, you won't realize how toxic it is until you get out and see what normal looks like. A boys-club mentality among VP's, SVP's & CIO with most having the emotional intelligence (EQ) of a wild goats. I've witnessed temper-tantrums, screaming, calling people out in meetings, finger pointing and demeaning behavior in public in my years there. The last 7 years more so than my experience before. Some VP's believe that to get ahead (in what is a  culture of VP's competing with each other) you have to do unethical things so much that it's become the norm. Most don't even realize they are doing it anymore.  My recommendation is take a job there if you absolutely need one, get some experience and then get out before the culture sucks the life right out of you.

Management is biased.  They want to run it like a family business and put their own people at forefront.  They lack the vision to take this company or department forward.  Poor man-management skills.

headline: Awesome Company
pros: As a corporate employee the company provides great pay & a phenomenal benefits package - Medical, dental, vision, short and long term disability, life insurance, pre-paid legal, 401k with a match, and a very generous amount of PTO and sick time.  Employer sponsored pension after two years of service. Cut-in program for registered staff allows you to earn commission in addition to salary. It should be noted that the benefits on the franchise side are different - they depend on the franchise owner.
cons: As a registered staff member the hours are inflexible. Tied to the desk 8:30-5, Mon-Fri with no option of working from home at all. We are forced claim a half hour lunch break each day on our time card, however the expectation is that you eat at your desk and work through lunch.  As an advisor you can come and go as you please and work from home and often or as little as you'd like - but not as staff.  Job responsibilities, expectations and accountability are incredibly high, leading to equally high levels of stress.  There is no path for registered staff who want to be advisors, though this IS available on the franchise side.

headline: The #1 Financial Service Company with the utmost integrity and strong values
pros: The culture, the people, the financial health and the overall investment to grow the organization. Diversity of business with advice and wealth management, asset management, insurance and annuities and auto & home allow Ameriprise to be uniquely positioned and continue to remain profitable even in a volatile market.  An excellent organization where one can add value and contribute regardless of level. An organization that has a lot of opportunity.
cons: Titles sometimes are not as competitive with the industry. Pay close attention to the cash incentives. They might appear lower in target but that is because you have an opportunity to leverage your bonus up to 200%..  Historically Ameriprise has paid out above target considering the financial health of the company has been so strong.

headline: Not what it used to be
pros:
Location - The corporate office is at the heart of downtown Minneapolis, lots of options for food and entertainment.

Benefits - Definitely above par, even for financial services companies. Between insurance, retirement contribution matches, and subsidies for public transportation (since downtown parking is a pain), and pretty generous vacation time...even though days have to be reserved for holidays.

Team Dynamic (minus management) - Honestly speaking, the group of people I worked with in the sweet spot of my time here were very talented, and we pulled off a lot of quality work in the midst of some of the biggest corporate idiocy I've ever seen. A lot of these people left to pursue other opportunities, which diminishes the aspect of great co-workers.
cons:
Crony-ism - Name a big company, especially a big financial services company, where brown-nosing and manager double-talk doesn't exist and that's where you should work. It's bad, but it's most likely par for the course.

Management temper-tantrums and passive-aggressiveness -  I mean, it is Minnesota, so 'Minnesota Nice' is probably to be expected...and some of the conference room meetings are stuff of legend.

headline: Great Leadership and Great Company!
pros: This company has a lot of great leadership and is very well organized. The people care about their reps and staff, and the level of service to clients is outstanding. I enjoy working here.
cons: Sometimes the level of paperwork required for compliance can be overwhelming; however, if you have a good system of organization and distribution of work in your local office, I believe you can establish a system that doesn't take too much time away from client meetings. This company is a master at protecting their reps, which is why there are a lot of established ways and forms for getting things accomplished.

headline: Devops Engineer
pros: good coordination with one another
cons: No discussions on the Bugs

headline: Good entry level opportunities.
pros: Ameriprise has entry level positions available for those who want to pursue a career in the financial services industry. Series 7 training was free and also available to those whose roles didn’t require FINRA registration. By participating in “brown-bag” lunch presentations, one can learn about other parts of the company and network. There was also a very good mentoring program available. For instance, I received mentorship from someone who was three pay grades above me.
cons: I observed some prejudice against those at the entry level positions. While there are many employees who don’t seek advancement within the company, the negative tone wasn’t warranted. There was also a bureaucratic culture that often seemed more interested in self-preservation than maximizing success. I met some wonderful people at Ameriprise, but it required persistence.

headline: Golden Handcuffs
pros: Great PTO and the health insurance is affordable.  The HR does a good job remaining balanced in disputes between bosses and employees. Decent work accommodations: gym, clinic, cafeteria, and convenience store on site. Dress code is business casual, but there is no restriction against tattoos, dye jobs, or piercings.
cons: Very demanding, fast paced no matter what department.  Seems like 25% of the job is being aware of and working within or around office politics and relationships.  Expectation of salaried workers is 45-60 hours per week (depending on "band" level).  Meeting all job expectations is not enough!  In order to advance, the expectation is to perform at a "meeting expectations" level of the next position higher for at least a year.  Once promoted, you are expected to exceed expectations very quickly in the role.  Company goes through CONSTANT technology, product, policy, and organizational structure changes.

headline: Great place to work
pros: The people were great to work with and I really learned a lot.
cons: Sometimes dealing with the public can be a challenge.

headline: Churn
pros: Licensing paid for and other new advisors in the office are great - they feel each other's pain and help each other out as much as they can. If you survive (big if) you can make some serious money. Looks like it takes 5 years of stress to get to that point where you might breathe.
cons: Leadership in this office seems to burn through new employees and then keeps the leads and clients once the newbie is gone. New employees literally are told they are not making the company any money, so they should be grateful while they are still there. Harsh words. New group forced to use each other for support and for help learning software systems from each other post-licensing. For a company this large, either this office is missing the training program, or the whole company thinks Kaplan and some videos is all there is to training and development.

headline: Solid Corporate Employer
pros: Salary is very competitive in career filed as well as in a larger city like Minneapolis. Ameriprise offers one of the best retirement benefits in place. They offer a 5% match of 401(k)/Roth IRA AND they offer a separate employer PAID RETIREMENT account--after one year of full-time employment they start making payments from 2-20% into that account, this is in addition to the 5% matching program. So if you're younger and make it to working 20 years with the company you'll have 25% of your income being contributed to your retirement BEFORE adding 5 or more percent. This is a pretty big deal. So if you're a long-term planner consider retiring from Ameriprise. Ameriprise also offers basic-free financial planning to all their employees. Ameriprise's medical benefits are decent, nothing worse or crazy better than the competition. I pay about 60 bucks a pay period for a PPO with a deductible of about 1500 that then pays 80/20. Prescription drug benefits are through ExpressScripts which is difficult to deal with but you eventually get the hang of it and than most your scripts are pretty cheap. If you're working from Minneapolis, Ameriprise provides a FREE health clinic where you can do most of your medical appointments. They have a nurse practitioner who can write scripts and plenty of nurses to evaluate all your aches and pains. They also offer free lab work and inoculations. If you're on a high-deductible or HSA plan this would be a great way to get most of your medical appointments free of charge and the clinic staff is great. I have stopped seeing my primary care physician all together and only see specialists now. They also offer physical therapy at a great discount on campus. Minneapolis has a gym although it is at a cost to the employee but minimal like 15-25 bucks a month. In Minneapolis there are some treadmill working stations and some employee provided fitness classes. Some leadership is very open to non-traditional work lifestyle like frequent telecommuting or working from other offices. Ameriprise has a pretty good working from home setup and stipend if you work from home more than 80% of the time. The leave policy as a first year employee is not too attractive but you are allowed after your first year of employment to buy up to 40 hours of personal time off, so if you have a big vacation planned or the similar this is a nice benefit versus taking leave without pay in bulk or not having the option to take time off. Ameriprise also offers maternity leave (I believe it is 5 weeks at some percentage but I am not positive). Ameriprise offers 5 sick leave days, not a lot but better than rolling those days into PTO hours as lots of companies have moved towards. As a salary employee you also do not have to report your hours worked. Which means you could go weeks or even months without reporting your time. The only time you report is when you missed work. And as a salary employee you only need to report 4 or more missed hours. For example, if you miss work for 2 hours you do not have to report that leave. This is very useful for doctors appointments, arriving late, leaving early et cetera. I was able to negotiate my salary in 2014 so I do believe you should try and not accept their first offer. I was able to negotiate 8k. My current salary only has changed 2% each year of the two I have been employed which is better than nothing since some employers don't always give raises. Also there is an end of the year bonus that usually gets paid out after January evaluations in February. My first year bonus was 23% of my salary which I thought was fair. In my role I feel that there is a very good work/life balance. There are weeks that I work far more than 40 hours but then there are weeks where I could work 0-30 and be OK with my work load. Ameriprise supplements Minneapolis public transportation commuters. Ameriprise offers underground heated and secure parking for bicycles. Ameriprise offers lots of different cultural committees and events and also offers a lot of moral improving committees, even one call the Fun Committee. Ameriprise offers in building cafeterias that a slightly subsidized. Ameriprise offers employee-to-employee recognition awards where any employee can recognize another employee and some of these recognitions have monetary value. Ameriprise makes it very easy to recognize your coworkers and show your appreciation opposed to a simple thank you.
cons:
The mid-year and annual employee review/evaluation process/technology is awful. It is VERY time-consuming and repetitive. It takes most employees 8 hours to complete. It is high redundant and depending on your leadership likely not used. It by far is my least favorite thing about working at Ameriprise and many agree it is an awful system.

Some leadership or business sectors are very different than others, which causes a culture of "the haves" and "have nots." Ameriprise should work to make the whole company work similarly. I have heard from non-head quarter's employees that they feel like they don't get the same benefits as HQ employees get and even as an HQ employee I see that as a con.

I haven't tried but I have heard from some that it is hard to get promotions from with-in the company. Also there were layoffs in 2016 but not extensive but still worth mentioning.

There could be more internal and external trainings available.

headline: The worst corporate experience in 20 years
pros: Good benefits, great cafeteria, reasonable maturity in business processes, reasonable (but not great) money, open to some employee growth, good location.
cons: Overall the management system is set up to compete with each other and leaders act like animals in a jungle. Ridiculous politics, incompetence at senior levels, rewards handed out to unethical people, and overall absence of executives. This company is successful by accident, not design.

headline: Financial advisor

headline: Tough gig, minimal trainig, but lots of money making potential
pros: Lots of independence and the ability to build a practice as large as your heart desires.  Fair payout, and constant advances in technology help make the client experience easier for both the advisor and the client.  Solid marketing campaigns on TV help to legitimize the brand.  Nearly no limit to upside potential. Once you've built a referral based practice, you're set.
cons: Lack of training.  Basically a sales job.  If you can't build a client base, you won't make any money.  If you're adverse to cold calling, this may not be the job for you.  Difficult to make money in first year or two.  Most of the training comes on the job.

headline: Good Good Company

Good way to get your foot in the business.

Fun office setting as everyone is young and excited to work

headline: People do not leave jobs; they leave leaders
pros: Ameriprise, as a company, is solid.  They continue to grow and acquire new companies.  They have an excellent benefits package.  Insurance costs are relatively inexpensive.  There are many good areas with very dedicated employees and leaders.
cons: Specific to technology only:  Highly political with what I view as corruption in technology at the VP and higher levels.  Tenured employees are not valued; instead, they are often pushed out through passive aggressive tactics such as unjustified low review ratings, being put on performance improvement plans for menial items, slowly taking away value add work responsibilities and making the work environment uncomfortable.  Politics and knowing the right people is the way to get promoted.  Nice is frowned upon.  Aggressiveness is rewarded.  VPs and above do not get along with each other which causes hostility between tech teams.

headline: A good company to start for salary
pros:
good salary
healthy work environment
top level management  is very good
cons:
no career  growth
learning depends on process to process.

headline: Client Service Manager
pros: relaxed environment most of the time.
cons: managers do not stay up to date with technology

headline: Most definitely a benefit to my college experience
pros: The people were so great. Every one that I came in contact with were personable and wanted to genuinely show me what it was like to work in Private Investment management. I was given actual tasks to do (not just run for coffee) and was busy almost all of the time.
cons: I had to commute about an hour each way but saying that, there are different offices that you are able to intern in.

headline: Franchise employee
pros: Flexibility, opportunity to fill many roles
cons: Because it is a franchise there is not any checks and balances system for employers.

headline: Marketing Manager
pros:
-Colleagues I interacted with on a daily/weekly basis were across the board professional, courteous and competent. 
-Director-level and VP-level leaders did not meddle in work and empowered their employees to do the work for which they were hired.
cons: -Marketing is not a focus for the firm and budgets continue to be slashed resulting in overworked employees

headline: Great company!
pros: Mid-west company values, benefits, and culture in the middle of sin city.  Great company with great people.  Leadership cares about employees and their development, work-life balance, and success.
cons: Continue to drive a culture where people want to come to work every day and give it their all.

headline: Expensive but good training
pros: Ameriprise prides itself on financial planning and has good support.
cons: Ameriprise is really expensive for the Advisor and mutual fund companies.

headline: Depends on the franchise owner
pros: The Pro's will come and go depending on the franchise owner. For myself, I enjoy gaining a lot of good experience working with many different clients. Working and getting hands on experience while in college is great and helps set me apart.
cons: The Con's will come and go depending on franchise owner. The work environment is not the best, many things or disorganized, keeping track of records is hard, and even making sure the computers are up to date is a part of my responsibility.

headline: Mixed Emotions
pros:
Training
Culture
Resources
Friendly (and educated) Corporate Staff
Technology Focus
Premium Company
Stability
cons:
Every experience is different based on the franchise vs employee platform
Lots of changes going on lately in the company (especially with the new DOL laws)
After 12 years, lost my trust/faith in them (changing culture and values) - so I am trying to write my experience over 11 years vs my negative experiences throughout the past year.
High costs (nickel and dime for everything)
Lower industry payout
Strict Compliance

headline: Advisor
pros: Leaving the office was the best part.
cons: They micromanage. You report numbers 3 times a day. Low payouts compared to the industry. They use proprietary products.

headline: Very unstructured
pros: Great people and low-stress environment
cons: Did clerical work 90% of the time and don't learn a lot or interact with the financial planner much on a day to day basis

headline: Associate Financial Advisor
pros: Working as an AFA means working for a franchisee so the experience will be different depending on the advisor you work for.  In my experience, the company has done an amazing job from the time it became an independent firm spun-off American Express.  The firm has been expanding the product options, improving technology and started to expand into higher net worth clients.  Since you work with a franchisee the atmosphere tends to be less company-like and more relaxed.  Teams tend to be smaller and you will get exposure to all facets of the business from operations, to financial planning and finally to investments.  Salaries are competitive but that depends on the franchisee since they are the ones that select the pay scales.
cons: You are working for a small franchisee group so you don't have access to "HR", or a benefits department, or a structure that would make it easier to understand who is in charge of what.  You will wear many hats but as long as you like it it's a great place to work at.

headline: Lacks organizational direction in AAC
pros: Ameriprise knows how to throw an employee party! They were quick to award trophies and host formal events. Well kept office in downtown Minneapolis.
cons:
The call center I was in completely lacked organizational direction. Upon calling my team clients usually waited at least five minutes to reach a rep to then be transferred to a service group. As a financial advisor my role was essentially an operator. 
There essentially was no licensing program. While all other firms I've worked with provided classes or mentor programs to succeed, Ameriprise only payed for the exam and books. Most all of my colleagues took the exams 2-3 times before passing.
Managers do not invest time in any of their employees but the ones who are leading in numbers. Many do not have even one on one checks ins because managers don't see value in investing that time.

headline: Legal Affairs Manager
pros: Benefits are equivalent to industry wide local companies
cons: As with all new jobs, each firm has its own culture, which can be trying at times.

headline: Client Relationship Manager
pros: Very good training and environment. Excellent location and facility in Downtown Minneapolis with motivated and fun co-workers.
cons: Incentive plan constantly changing and some managers were very controlling.

headline: Investment Advisor Analyst
pros: A nice and relaxing work environment
cons: Not enough career opportunities and room for growth

headline: Registered Client Service Associate
pros: Appreciated being able to upload my client documents directly from my desk. Management did not micro-manage and were extremely pleasant. Weekly calls with operations manager allowed you to discuss anything and share where you would like your career to take you.
cons: Computer system was not as current as it could have been for the financial industry.

headline: Mid Management
pros: Great bonus and pay structure. Good employee centricity. Half of the work force is young and hence they really work. Understanding management --- Do Not lie for leaves, tell the truth , you get them.
cons: Micro Politics , half the population is dead weight on the organization. They have and are interested in everything going around, other than work. Unqualified people in meaningful roles. These lot never respect their peers, reportees and even their superiors. Odd hours to work. 2-10:30. Not much work from home when you rally require.

headline: AAC Advisor
pros:
-Ameriprise is a large Fortune 500 company who is a leader in the industry. I gained a lot of insight into the industry and learned a lot. It's a great company to work for. Great benefits too! Great vertical career progression. 
-90% of my coworkers had a 4year college degree, so employees are educated. 
-Some of the best people I've met work here.
cons:
-Not as diverse as it could be. 
-Career opportunities to move from one field to another is extremely difficult to come by (example: moving from sales to HR or from HR to marketing).
-REALLY needs to focus on its diversity strategy. During my time, all the women of color left the department (I bet it is something only I've noticed, which is not a surprise). Turn over ratio is even greater for aspiring women advisors.

headline: So so
pros: Front line people are solid
cons: Upper management below average and grasping to keep company competitive

headline: So so
pros: Front line people are solid
cons: Upper management below average and grasping to keep company competitive

headline: Paraplanner
pros: The company provides great education, ongoing tools and process training webinars and resources, strong compliance and clear communication about what we need to do to stay legal and keep our clients and our practices protected.
cons: The Franchise division completely depends on the advisor or team you work with. As an advisor you must constantly grow your practice or your payout decreases potentially significantly. Financial Planning is strongly encouraged, so if you prefer to be a broker only, you should join a team that will allow you to fill that need. As an employee/staff - again - it completely depends on the individual(s) you work for. The advisors have a lot to do and a lot of areas to be knowledgeable about, so a team practice is likely a better bet for staff.

headline: Team Leader

headline: Project Manager
pros:
Most of the benefits are very good, like on site healthcare, generous planned time off, matching 401k, and recent emphasis on philanthropic volunteering and community giving.  Emphasis on diversity at many levels.

Many employee networks to become connected and grow in leadership skills.  Emphasis on employee development, and many things can be tuition reimbursed.  Working from home is possible but depends on the leader, role, and department "comfort" with the arrangement.  

Free coffee and ice/water machines in the break room.

Departments still have some discretionary $ for employee engagement and celebration/outings.

Dress code is allows blue jeans on Fridays.

People are friendly and make it a great place to work.
cons:
Employee development is highly regarded but can feel slow to translate into job transitions. Posted jobs can read extremely specific and targeted to either outside candidates or specific persons with unique combinations of skill set.  As a result, many of them stay on the posting boards for a long time or get re-posted and like a home on the market, there is caution before one thinks about applying.  

Training department and technology is slow to advance to modern methodologies.  Current flavor of the company is Lean.  

Director & VP heavy currently.  

Company requires mid year and annual performance reviews.

headline: The truth hurts Ameripuke! If Tommy Lee Jones only knew.
pros: Air conditioned building. Ample parking. Nice office chairs.  Large professional call center. Good view of the airport. I guess I have to give them credit for the paid training and paying for your licenses. After that, it's all down hill.
cons:
Where to begin? The Air Conditioned Building is just a front for a White Collar Sweatshop. The work is tedious and boring. The pay($15/hr) is lousy for what you do...handle a bombardment of phone calls dealing with everything you can't possibly imagine using a dozen different user-unfriendly software/computer systems. 
Once the training is over, the honeymoon is over. The workload seems to be ever-increasing. You are juggling half a dozen things all day, phone calls, e-mails, follow-ups, etc... This company takes multi-tasking to the H-N-L....Hole Nother Level! They came to Vegas for one reason...to take advantage of cheap labor. And they are masters at it. Expect to come home brain dead everyday.

Very little room for advancement. On the rare occasion a higher paying position does become available, expect to be competing against dozens of your co-workers all of whom applied for the same job regardless of their qualifications. The company then goes through the motions(dog and pony show) of interviewing everyone who applied. Again, regardless of their qualifications. 
When you inquire of management what it is you need to do in order to advance, they'll give you a list of things to do. After you do them they will give you a new list of things to do... and you still won't get the promotion! Management always smiling, telling you what a great job you're doing.

The disparity between low level worker pay and "C"-level pay has to be one of the worst in corporate America!

Lousy free coffee.

headline: Avoid if you can
pros: They pay for your initial licenses.  Sadly that is it.  They used to provide significant ongoing training but that has fallen by the wayside as a newer "team" model has been adopted.
cons:
I want to be clear that this is not a review of a branch office but rather a corporate department The Ameriprise Advisor Center or AAC as they refer to it.  
Pay:
When i started pay was a combination of base salary and comission.  By the time i left the pay structure had been altered to one of bonus and base.  Your bonus is determined by 2 factors your team hitting its target revenue and how well you get along with your manager.  Even meeting your number means you will see a comission payout of about 10 to 11%.  The number is adjusted quarterly and annually.  If you have experience in this industry you know how low of a grid payout that is.  A typical producet is going to be expected to generate 150k to 200k GDC per year.  They will alter pay plans annually, I watched people have issues purchasing homes due to the constant pay plan changes.

Clients:
At one point earlier in my tennure with the organization their were many clients worth working with.  The organization solely works with orphaned clients that come from Ameriprises field advisors.  These clients were typically cast off from the first advisor becuase the advisor could not generate any more revenue off of them.  Suffice to say many of these clients are more than a little disgrunteled with the firm.  You will be expected to sell each of them a financial plan when you initially meet with them.  Most of the clients do not have the assets to warrant purchasing a financial plan.  Thses clients have also been called to death at this point, sometimes several times in the same week.

Management:
The management of the AAC is broken down into 3 levels, the team manager, the directors (managers bosses) and the VP running the department.  Management definitely has a bro culture mentality about it.  Reminded me of highschool and college locker rooms.  

People and culture:
Sadly the quality of people to work with diminished greatly as i worked there.  Many would be amazed to know that people like this were allowed to handle other peoples money and advise them on what to do with it.  Many a high five did i witness after someone dropped a "rava bomb" ie convinced a client to purchase an annuity.  This type of mentality is rampant in the department.  Client suitablilty really is a secondary concern to meeting the teams revenue number.  As the training has fallen off dramatically new "specialists" have been brought in to sell for the sales people as the newer sales people have little to no experience selling the financial products they are recommending.  0 to 6 months experience is not uncommon.  It is not uncommon for an advisor to be drunk or high during the work day, probably to deal with the misery and stress of being there.

Roles and expectations:
Be prepared to work 55 to 70 hours per week.  If you are newer your job will consist of setting appoints for the sales roles or advisors or doing their paperwork.  If you are in a selling roles you will hold 8 to 12 client meeting per day with mostly unqualified clients who have had this exact same meeting with one of the previous advisors several times.  You will also be expected to sell a financial plan to eveyone you meet with.  Anyone with tenure in this industry knows this is unethical.  The place essentially functions as a boiler room and i feel sorry for clients who through no fault of their own have their money there.  

In summary this place is toxic.  Avoid it at all costs.  Waiting tables is a better job than this

headline: Paraplanner
pros: Flexible, fun environment with personal one on one training and mentoring.
cons: Not too many cons, just not the rapid growth I was hoping for.

headline: Company culture
pros: Good benefits, Senior leaders are smart, conservative company
cons: Below market pay, micro-management, too many silos, no individual accountability

headline: Sales consultant
pros: Leadership development is a high priority in this department and you'll get a fair amount of exposure to the executive leadership team.
cons: Field leadership has little to some influence with franchisees.  Titles matter way more than it should.

headline: Associate Project Manager
pros: Great leadership and at both the director and VP level.  Surrounded by a lot of people who are very good at their jobs.
cons: Lack of culture in the technology department. Very reliant on outdated software and hardware.  Lack of success planning.

headline: Good company, tough gig

cons: Tough job.  As an advisor, you're primary focus starting out isn't financial planning, rather activities around networking.  I don't know how many cold calls I've made.

headline: Great Place To Work.
pros: Challenging Work. Latest Technology used.
cons: No Standard Process. Coordination between Business and Technology.

headline: Vice President
pros: Excellent people, commitment to development

headline: Digital Archivist
pros: Working at the Amerprise Office in Modesto has been an amazing opportunity for me, they offered me the job right after I graduated from High School and my salary has been all spent on my college tuition. The office was small, so quiet, and I worked with some really great people. Also I got to work with what interests me, computers, for my entire job.
cons: There weren't really any downsides to working there. If I had to put at least one I'd say location. The office is located in the downtown area of Modesto, and crime seems to happen all around us. Our office was totally secure, cameras, alarms, special locks, but we get crime reports near us all the time, and occasionally some happened right in front of us.

headline: Never Again
pros: Everything started out great, but then!
cons: The business module was not sustainable.

headline: Ok..ok

headline: Customer Service Representative

headline: Best in Class
pros: Client centric firm with full capabilities.
cons: Corporate channel has a lower payout than the independent side.

headline: Good company, but things are not always what they seem to be.

headline: good company

headline: Great Job

headline: Good place to start

Facilities - Transport facility, Game Zone, etc. are good
cons: Compensation structure - very confusing, very complex, it is meant to be an employee retention tool but it is used by HR to fool prospective new employees

cons: Limited advancement opportunities in field office unless you want to be advisor. Base pay for RCSA starts at $45k if you have 0 experience. But with experience $52-55k. Annual salary increases are 2-4%. The growth in compensation comes from bonus from advisors but they are not required to cut in. It may take a couple of years  for good cut-ins come your way

headline: Great company to work

- Salary hike is good
-Work environment is cool
-Engage you in different activites
cons: There is no sucj cons

headline: Review

cons: Everything is going great -- they are position very well.

headline: Poor compensation

headline: Mixed bag

cons: Very financially conservative and doesn't take many risks.

headline: Meh

Benefits 
Ok place to work

headline: Senior Associate

headline: ROL

headline: Intern
pros:

- Good direction given
- Steady workload
cons: - Work can rather be monotonous

headline: Good Employer
pros: Company policies are excellent

headline: Employee
pros: Leaving the office to go home
cons: The environment and the work relationship causes a lot stress. It's not a professional work environment. The owner is always "right" no matter how much he gets it wrong. Ninety-nine percent of the clients are below the benchmark (S&P 500). I believe clients should take their money and run.

headline: I work for a franchise owner as an AFA
pros: depends on who your franchise owner is.... but the company does sponsor great training days
cons: depends on your franchise owner...

headline: I work for a franchise owner as an AFA

cons: No cons. Excellent experience as an intern

headline: Financial Planning Assistant

cons: May or may not receive benefits, it will depend on the financial advisor.

headline: Awesome Corporate Culture
pros: Loved it all, best employer I have ever had.
cons: Wouldn't change a thing.  This is a great company to work for.

headline: Review
pros: Good learning and environment, good for beginners.
cons: Hand written data is a pain.

headline: No growth plan, pays salaries way below market
pros: Vacation time is okay. Culture is laid back.
cons: At the beginning of 2015 our said our growth plan was to "Keep doing what we're doing." Unsurprisingly, that resulted in 2% year over year revenue growth. Now in 2016, his growth plan is to control costs. Those costs are employee salaries. I make 40% less than Ameriprise's own stated minimum pay range for my position. Time to move on.

headline: Solid
pros: Downtown location, building, history, strong capital position, strategic, solid leadership, strength in marketplace, culture and values
cons: lots of layers, promotions and moving up, leaning new skills, being challenged, slow pace

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Worked with and helped a lot of great people.
cons: I worked for an independent contractor who retired, there were no options for me.

headline: planning assistant
pros: It was an  easy commute. The work is fairly easy. The view was wonderful. You can make a ton of money once you get your CFP.  I liked helping people with their investments.
cons: I worked in a toxic office. The Senior manager was awful.  The training was not thorough.  My coworkers were also very toxic.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Great training, got paid to study for licensing exams.
cons: They push internal products and basically make you drink the Kool-Aid on their insurance products. Once sold, clients are locked into products with high fees and low returns.

headline: Employee Welfare & Growth
pros: Leaders provide support to analyst as and when required and try to promotes positivity within the team.
cons: Management seems to be least interested to reduce attrition within their business unit and hence difficult for new analysts to survive.

headline: Sr. Manager
pros: Good culture of teamwork.  People are very professional.  A great industry-leading set of ideas in certain business areas.
