headline: Kind of okay
pros:
Easy work.
No need of any mind.
Even a trained monkey can do some processes
cons:
Work Pressure.
Most of the people in the process end up staying late
Systems are on shared basis.

headline: Advisor Associate
pros: Flexible schedule, autonomy. great advisory experience
cons: Low pay, long hours, low benefits

headline: Client Services Coordinator
pros: This has been the best job I have had in quite some time. The branch staff here in Salt Lake City are so friendly and knowledgeable. I really feel like I'm part of a family and not just an employee
cons: I have not one single complaint about my position!

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Terrific leadership, people, and coworkers.  Everyone works together to be of best service to clients.
cons: Locations are sparse in Southern California

headline: Great
pros: Good pay and great location
cons: Not good work very boring

headline: For Analytics team in India: Good if you dont want to work. No performance based growth and lot of favoritism
pros:
-Good work life balance
-Provides transport and food facility
-Not too much work. If you want to work its OK, if you don't want then no one will push you
cons:
--Very bad salary structure (They will make sure that you don't understand it !)
--Growth is not performance driven rather its tenure driven. You spend some time in organization and you will get promoted. Doesn't matter if you performed good or bad.(This is actually true)
--Lot of favoritism in system. Manager only speak for the ones they like and they show same to the US people and India leadership
--Leadership is not aware of what happens at ground level. They only see the pictures which middle mangers show them

headline: Client Relationship Manager
pros: Pros are dependent of the type of office you work in.  I worked for two Franchisee Advisors in a small office.  Great working environment, decent year end bonus compensation, unlimited/flexible vacation and free lunch on your birthday.
cons: Small business does not provide very good benefits, health care subsidy doesn't even cover the cheapest plan in the Healthcare Exchange; no retirement plan and not a lot of room for advancement or promotion.

headline: Good company to work for.
pros:
- Robust company policies
- Approachable management
- Good infrastructure
- Provides good facilities to employees such as transport, food, medical benefits etc.
- Depending on the profile, a person gets to interact with US team and gets good exposure.
- Company is growing and hence, will generate more opportunities in the future.

In short, here, a person can achieve work-life balance if he wants.
cons:
- Unpredictable management moves and changes. You never know when a new change will be introduced.
- Talent and skillset disparity. People with unequal skills and/or qualifications could be seen working in the same position.
- Not much status of India team in front of US team.

headline: Group Leader
pros: Lot to learn from people around.
cons: Work life balance is not there.

headline: Manager
pros: Diverse talent, competitive wages,  comprehensive benefits package, professional atmosphere,  room for growth and development,  client focused and strong community relations.
cons: Work life balance can be a challenge when the change agenda for the organization is large. A lot of departments seem understaffed which makes a lot of work bottleneck and requires employees, even exempt  associates to put in a lot of extra hours per week and on the weekends to manage the workload.

headline: Good company
pros: Good entry level job, decent pay, family feeling with coworkers, great benefits. I got two licenses while employed there that they pay you to get.
cons: Technical training is not very good, they like to pretty much baptize by fire and you learn on the fly. Dealing with field staff can be irritating when they call in, especially when they need something done and waited till the absolute last minute to do it.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Great company with lots of opportunity.
cons: Tough to get started as a financial advisor.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Great company with lots of opportunity.
cons: Tough to get started as a financial advisor.

headline: FINANCIAL ADVISOR
pros:
AMP has excellent training program
They teach you about client personality types, questioning, which i like the most. for newhire FA's training is top notch. 
Great  product,
cons: i dont think their marketing idea  Compared to other companies in the industry are that effective in getting business. Employee turnover ratio is very high.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Positive culture dedicated to advisor success
cons: Corporate vision diffused occasionally detracts from overall success.

headline: Certain leadership needs to go
pros: Good focus on strategy as to how to manipulate laws to squeeze profits from clients and charge back advisors for everything even though the firm ready takes haircuts from advisor commissions for overhead.
cons: Home office leaders encouraged to be rude to each other and employees.  Sexual harassment tolerated at the top.  Rewarded for pushing work to others and merely reporting on it.  Year end alignment ratings are a popularity contest.

headline: Most dysfunctional company
pros: Competitive salary, smart colleagues and good benefits
cons: Ameriprise is the most dysfunctional company I've worked for and management is oblivious. Culture is blame-based and fearful. Promotions and key assignments are usually given to "friends" of management. Hours are long and vacation time is a myth.

headline: Financial Planning Intern
pros: Great Company to work for with good culture
cons: Compensation is not the best but is doable

headline: No way
pros: Training is unbelievably great. They have a nice cafeteria.
cons: The service center is a boiler room. Pressure Pressure Pressure. Management is hostile, employees have their jobs threatened daily. Plan on working 12 hour days and bonus and commissions messed with. The VP of department is trying to run the place like boot camp. They have turned over an enormous number of great employees only to be left with the one's that are willing to tolerate the treatment. Once your in the service center they are not letting you go to any other department either.

headline: Wholesaler
pros: It's a caring culture, with good work / life balance, leaders who are flexible and have real expectations of employees and they act with high integrity.  People are a great, caring group who put the clients and advisors first.
cons: Salary, and company politics, technology, budgets, and lack of career opportunities. Generally technology and service areas are places that need improvement.  Especially since they are very tight with spending money on important people and tech.

headline: Difficult but rewarding
pros: Financial services is a difficult field to break into but can be very rewarding. Ameriprise offers a lot of training and support.
cons: Long hours. Constant cold calling in the evenings. Need more balance between helping the customer and just selling products.

headline: Decent company
pros: Ethical, fairly flexible, accessibility to superiors
cons: Career development, pay could be relatively better, very narrow company focus at times

headline: Good Company
pros: Ameriprise is having a good work life balance
cons: No learning opportunity after spending 2 years

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Benefits and work life balance. PTO is great. Large enough company to continue to develop professionally. Integrity is high, community involve is sincere.
cons: Not always a pioneer, usually a fast follower by design. Has a reputation for catering to a less sophisticated client, not true as huge strides have been made over the past decade.

headline: Great Opportunity
pros: Lots of room to learn and grow with the company. I felt cherished by my financial advisor.
cons: There are a lot of frequent changes in contact and document management which can be confusing to adapt to.

headline: Poor leadership
pros: Benefits overall are above anywhere else I've seen. Flexible work arrangements are available if employees push aa a a a a
cons: Leadership is so disconnected from employees it's unreal.  I was in school getting an MBA while there and management did the exact opposite of what managers should do (zero transparency, executive decisions, favoritism, lack of employee input, little face time with managers).  Additionally, compensation is far below industry average, I make over 30% more in my new (very similar) role than I did at Ameriprise.

headline: Would never recommend Ameriprise
pros: Ameriprise offers competitive benefits.  They have an excellent severance package and paid time off policy.
cons: Senior leadership is horrible.  I've worked in several areas within the company for over 22 years and the reoccurring theme is that the senior leaders do not have the people skills necessary to relate to their teams or foster a positive work environment,

headline: Mediocre one size fits all
pros: fee based financial planning combined with asset management and insurance as opposed to wirehouse free plan to gather assets approach
cons: One size fits all with "happy meal" that consisted of a plan, a wrap account, a variable annuity and disability or life insurance. Not client centric, just sales driven. One regional coordinator suggested "dropping RAVA bombs" to increase monthly production, meaning sell some variable annuities and choose the biggest up front commission.  Ideas for growing book of business wearing thin.  Like seminars?  How are you going to fill them?  Management played games with things like which mutual funds were available for sale on fee based platforms (American Funds wouldn't pay so couldn't play), questionable management of direct offices with regional and above being disconnected from on the ground reality.

headline: Intern
pros: Great experience if you want to pursue a career in finance
cons: Interns required to do some tedious, administrative tasks.

headline: Learning organization
pros: Good place to learn financial services concepts
cons: poor culture, almost like a government organization now

headline: Client Service Manager
pros: Great company overall.  Very conservative and I was pleased with how my portfolio grew.  I also, was impressed with how the franchise owner ran his business.
cons: When working for a franchise owner, there are no benefits.  The salary was not enough to cover my basic expenses and insurance.

headline: I have been working at Ameriprise full-time (More than a year)
pros: Nice environment to work. No Excess workload.
cons: Technical aspects are bit less. Nothing to learn.

headline: Service Delivery/ Brokerage & SPS accounts
pros: You are constantly learning, and doing different tasks. I find that exciting.
cons: No room for growth. They make you feel like a number, not a person.

headline: Client Service Coordinator
pros: Great company. Extensive online training. Home Office in Minneapolis has well trained personnel. I have worked for this company for almost 8 years. Enjoy working here.
cons: There are no cons that I can think of. As with any job there are little things that are annoying but what job doesn't have them. Still a wonderful company.

headline: Vice President
pros: The company has a sound value proposition in the market place. A personal financial advisor with access to both proprietary and non proprietary products and the ability to prepare a comprehensive and detailed financial plan.
cons: The company chews through executives and HR people. It seems to lurch from one shiny object to the next and can over promise and under deliver to its distribution.

headline: Franchise
pros: Parent Ameriprise was good but worked for a franchise. Amerprise provided updated systems, helpful tools.
cons: Working for a franchise puts employees in the hands of the advisor, choose wisely. Worst boss and management ever. Treated employees terribly, low wages, no room for career growth, complete lack of communication, very high turnover. Again research throughly who you would be working for and find past employees.

headline: General Working Environment
pros: Caring; Nurturing; Supportive to employees
cons: Tool System can be challenging at times

headline: Boring
pros: Hours are good, no nights and weekends, clients are friendly.  Duties include answering the phone, scheduling appointments, ordering kitchen and office supplies.
cons: Don't get much paid time off. The job can be demanding and high stress.  No room for advance for  most positions.

headline: Senior Associate
pros: have their own Captive units
cons: Hiring at very fast pace for its wealth management business where resources for employees are less

headline: Financial Planning Assistant
pros: Solid marketing that creates a brand that clients can trust
cons: Bad overall tools and resources available to advisors

headline: Not worth the stress or the good compensation
pros: Ameriprise has a really good compensation and benefit package, if title and salary is all you care about.
cons: There is a reason this company is a constant revolving door, and unable to keep good employees for long periods. Poor culture, lack of senior leadership commitment (worst leadership I have ever worked with), minimum to no cross function collaboration (it is whoever screams the loudest or threatens more viciously that gets their way, at the expense of whoever is on their way). Leadership looks out for themselves, and not for the growth, integration, and edification of their employees or teams. Even within groups, there is competition, and there are leaders often meddling and trying to get into other group's scope to expand their territory. The impression given is that you constantly have to watch out and trust no one.

headline: Great
pros: Everything was great about working here
cons: None if any apply to cons

headline: Advisor Center Intern
pros: Fun and young atmosphere with great opportunities.
cons: Location and parking was a hassle.

headline: Process Engineer Intern Experience
pros: Great place to intern at. Great program, great opportunities to learn and network.
cons: No real cons. loved everything about it

headline: office manager
pros: Great place to work. enjoyment
cons: Must be an advisor to make any money

headline: Amazing company to work with
pros: Lot of learning, Nice working environment. ELT members are easily approachable
cons: I didnt find anything wrong with the company

headline: Be sure this is really what you want to do.
pros: Not a lot, you work with some nice people. They give you plenty of training, but it's all web based, spend lots of hours training from your desk.
cons: Want lots of time, hours in the office and expected to do client events and dinners regularly. Pay is never what they say it is.

headline: Sr. Collections Associate
pros: Get to learn new skills
cons: Over worked and way under paid.

headline: Associate Financial Advisor
pros: Great Access to information and to products.  The company really does provide a lot of material and resources for advisors to become experts in their field.  When we don't know the answers there is usually someone from home office who can provide the need guidance.
cons: You are basically running your own business and work on commission.  That is good and bad depending on the personality. There are a lot of compliance issues that you have to be on top of.  That is not a problem of Ameriprise, but of all financial services companies.

headline: Solid company with integrity. Good place to learn.
pros: Ameriprise works hard to serve clients at a high level. Whether in a support role or an advisor role, there's a sense of integrity. Always lots of work to do. Good selection of products - both proprietary and non - to offer clients.
cons: As a service associate supporting advisors it's easy to feel overburdened by the volume of work and the great variation between how each advisor works with associates.

headline: Nice place to work
pros: Great interaction with onshore , travel opportunities , good work enviornment
cons: No training for the Job , expected to be a jack of all trades , Poor Managerial leadership

headline: Team Environment
pros: Good Pay, good location to work.
cons: Tenure coworker not team oriented

headline: Team Environment
pros: Good Pay, good location to work.
cons: Tenure coworker not team oriented

headline: Solid Financial Services Company
pros: Great benefits, work life balance, and competitive pay.
cons: Technology is lacking, consensus based decision making is slow, CFO is the best in the business!

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Ameriprise as a company has high standards for it's employees and is very motivated to stay at the top of it's field as a leader in financial services.
cons: Ameriprise has very low job growth opportunity in some areas.  Many employees are very long tenured.

headline: Delegate
pros: allowed to work in an independent atmosphere
cons: Not a lot of in house training . Advisors are independent contractors and all costs go to them.

headline: Information Security Analyst
pros: Great company to learn and grow your talent. Provides good work life balance
cons: poor maintenance of facilities.

headline: Marketing analyst
pros:
-excellent pay
-great people
-great place to begin a career
cons: -things tend to move slower

headline: Former Service Associate
pros: Good benefits, annual bonuses and raises, procedures are documented and up-to-date most of the time
cons: very structured environment with little flexibility, uses off-shore vendors for almost everything

headline: My thoughts
pros: Great career opportunities, great work culture, excellent benefits, solid & financial sound company that provides great job security, promotes team work
cons: focus on numbers rather than overall interaction with customers

headline: Good way to get your foot in the door
pros: Baseline training in sales and financial planning concepts. No overhead or entrance fees as a trainee and option to open your own franchise as experience level grows.
cons: No asset management training in reality and low compensation structure. Forgiveable draw vs just a base salary and slash and burn treatment of your natural market.

headline: Executive
pros: Excellent benefits, work life balance doable,  and diversity
cons: Not sure assistants are paid competitively

headline: Corporate office employee
pros:
Good benefits and retirement funding.
Communication between departments has improved.
I found the work challenging, with adequate funding for projects.
Software support was adequate but not excellent.
I liked the work atmosphere and culture, and the amount of time spent in meetings was about right.
cons:
It is a complex business with many layers of management.
Not too many other things to list here.

headline: Investment Specialist
pros: For entrepreneurial individuals, and those willing to put in the time and effort, working at Ameriprise as a financial advisor offers incredible growth opportunity.
cons: Our industry is heavily regulated, and Ameriprise's advisor compliance requirements are very hard-nosed.  Unfortunately, because of the size of the company, there is less freedom to build a practice as you see fit; some of the tools available to independent advisors are flat out banned for Ameriprise advisors.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Not one 'pro'. From day one it was an awful experience. Promise you assistance to get started. Provided nothing but stress.
cons: Awful company to start your career as a financial adviser

headline: review
pros: flexible hours since the majority of work is completed online
cons: support at home office level is basic at best

headline: Worst organization ever
pros: Great mission statement, people in the trenches work very hard and want to be apart of something great
cons: Complete disconnect between CEO vision and sr management method of execution.  The flogging will continue until moral improves.

headline: Working here
pros: I love being downtown Minneapolis, close to everything. The company also offers great benefits with maternity leave included.
cons: Little move for movement, culture sometimes is difficult depending on department.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Very community minded, employees are given autonomy to get the job done, great executive leadership team, great benefits, average salary ranges for financial services company, bonus structure recognizes employees for contributions.
cons: No cons to share, liked working for the firm.

headline: Consulting project
pros: very friendly, welcoming of new ideas
cons: project goals kept changing over time

headline: Auditor
pros: Great company to work for, I liked the flexible work schedule and the benefits were generous including vacation time.  Leaders were good
cons: some departments micro manage to much, get disciplined for using sick days, need to log in and out when on breaks or lunch even when you are not on a phone queue

headline: Summer Internship was Great
pros: Do not know what other offices are like, but the Radford, VA office is fantastic. The manager is absolutely fantastic. This internship will be what you make of it. Whatever you want to learn, you will!
cons: Unfortunately, not a paid position.

headline: Consultant
pros: they have good benefits and competitive pay. all the people you'll work with are particularly friendly and welcoming to you.
cons: Long hours, but the scheduling is very flexible. Youll never go in for a weekend and fridays are typically half days during the summer, always a plus.

headline: Business Manager
pros: Solid company with a strong brand. Ethical Advisors committed to helping their clients reach their financial goals. Professional environment in which to work.
cons: There is a lot of regulatory angles to manage through which is expected given the financial climate we are in. Lots of paperwork to process even for what seems like a simple transaction.

headline: Service associate
pros: People, 30 min lunches.  That's pretty much it
cons: Job is down right depressing.  I've never seen so many people go on Fmla in ONE team only. the rest just quit due to frustration.  It's funny because they honestly think the pay is competitive among similar firms

headline: Ameriprise Advisor Center
pros:
1. Employee benefits (only because this is a corporation)
2. Its an ok place to start out if breaking into the industry ( to be fair i will give them that)
3. You get to at least share in the daily misery with some nice coworkers
4. If you're incapable of thinking for yourself or simply dont want to anymore, this is a great place to work!
5. If you have no morals or ethics and dont care about selling bad products to clients compared to the rest of the industry or having real advisor-client relationships with real people on the other side of the phone, this place is for you!
6. Makes you realize while working in the AAC (Ameriprise Advisor Center), the grass REALLY IS GREENER on the other side and things REALLY CAN GET WORSE.
7. If you argue/disagree with leadership/management, there is a good chance that you are smarter/more ethical/have higher sense of moral standards than you just might think.
8. Higher chances of receiving bigger bonuses if you can follow orders, and close your mouth regardless of what you are hearing is right or wrong.
9. Job security has increased since the AAC only gains 1 or 2 people for every 5-6 people that leave
cons:
1. AAC slogan is client first then team then individual; in reality, it is company first then team and individual then the client.
2.  ZERO TRANSPARENCY as sales metrics and goals are changed every quarter and probably 90% of the time, the metrics increase.  There is no direct formula to determine your overall quarterly bonus.  So an advisor could generate $50k of GDC (gross dealer concession) for the company and receive a $10k bonus (which is 20% and is already considered low in the industry) and the next quarter generate $60k of GDC and only receive a $8k bonus.
3. Based on the 2nd point just made, FC's and CRM's are "capped" at making a max of $80k-$90k per year (salary plus bonus) regardless of the GDC they generate.  As the sales director once said, "we can't pay people hundreds of thousands of dollars."
4. The "subjective" part of the quarterly bonus is determined by sales managers sitting behind a closed door and figuring out how to 1. keep bonus money in the "kitty" for themselves or the company at end of the year, and then 2. how much to compensate people they want to stay with the company and stay motivated, 3. how much to withhold from people they dont like regardless of how much revenue they've produced and how to go about communicating their reasoning for not giving out what that advisor rightfully deserves, or from people they think are planning on leaving anyways after they receive their bonus b/c theyve had enough of the high school bs so that, again, they can keep it in the "kitty." So instead of paying bonuses based on what you have actually done, bonuses are used as a tool, like dangling a carrot in front of a horse, as they are paid with what they expect from you the following quarter.
5. There is no way to build a book of business.  The Ameriprise AAC is only concerned with generating as much up-front revenue on the highest commissioned products possible.  It wouldnt be as bad if these products (annuities, mutual funds, life insurance) were the best or at least towards the top in the industry, but they are nowhere close.  The philosophy actually lived by is different than what is preached from upper management to sales management to advisors as once a client has generated all the revenue they possibly can in management's eyes, there is very little reason to continue speaking with the client on a regular basis and the calls and meetings with that client dwindle down to practically nothing.  If clients are called, it is only with the intent to sell something new or something else.  There is little to no intent to simply call a client to check in and see how they or their family is doing or work with them on financial aspects such as paying off their debts or establishing a budget.  This is viewed in the eyes of management as an inefficient use of time and a waste of money.
6. Management eavesdrops on phone calls and attempts to tell advisors what they should say to the client to eventually get them to buy or invest in what they want them to.
7. Very little product knowledge training
8. Very few career pathways; a CSC (dialer) can go to a CSA (service/paperwork), a CSA can go to an FC (financial consultant;focuses on selling financial plans to everyone on every call) or CRM (client relationship manager; focuses on selling whatever FC cant to client); CRM or FC to Sales Manager; that's about it
9. Reality is its a hybrid of a call center and a "boiler room"
10. Advisors are inept at doing their job mostly because they havent been trained on how to actually do it.
11. Other than the once a week meetings with management behind closed doors, advisors are called in to abrupt and sudden meetings with managers as they berate them on things that in reality dont even matter or are minimal in the grand scheme of things as their focus is hardly ever on the actual important things of the job or why the advisor failed to sell or solicit a financial plan to a client who has no need for one, is 80 years old or is making $12k/ a year and is disabled.  If an advisor is 5 minutes late for an employee meeting, you can almost guarantee that the advisor will spend at least 30 mins of their day sitting down and being berated and yelled at for being 5 mins late....Hmmm...Sounds similar to an event that occurred about 80 years ago overseas...  If you say something publicly that management thinks could be confrontational or critical or damages someone or something's image...you figuratively speaking, will be "taken behind the shed".
12. Management spends most of its time behind closed doors in the meetings they've created making fun of people, indulging in gossip, and discussing hypothetically if they had the chance, who they would want to punch in the face.
13. Keep losing good people
14. At least 35% of your day is spent in useless meetings created by the bureaucracy which is the corporate world and management.
15. Management will say to you whatever they need to in order for you to produce and generate more money for themselves and the company.
16.  Obviously at this point, you can probably assume the truth that yes, you are treated as a child, not as an adult. Micromanagement at its finest.

headline: ameriprise financial gurgaon

less duration of shift
good transport facility

stop playing musical chair and managers pet stories
unequal opportunities to GUYS as compared to woman folk
older lot making it difficult for any new project to be undertaken

Employees keep leaving so i have job security

Bonuses are not on production but how much your liked

headline: manager

headline: Amazing place to work!!

It was amazing working with Ameriprise India. Great Leadership team, excellent hierarchy. It encourages it's employees to push their boundaries and emerge as winners.
The employee engagement team does a great work.
cons: Salary package initially seems a bit low and the promotion cycle is often not practiced as in policies. However, it depends on an employees performance. If an employee performs extremely well, then sky is the limit. I suppose that is the case with every employer. Overall, Ameriprise is a great place to be!!

headline: Good place to get your training and then get out.

Top down management philosophy and employees are not engaged in decision making.  Leadership would rather listen to consultants instead of listening to their own employees.

headline: Team Leader

cons: Opportunities for advancement come along rarely. Levels of leadership vision are not aligned. Generally pay less than industry averages.

headline: Dump
pros: There are no pros to speak of.
cons: Magic tricks, and lots of broken promises.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Great department atmosphere, great group of people, very supportive to new comers. Fantastic work ethic and would recommend for employment. Management values work/life balance and always receive helpful feedback. Had great management and middle managers are great at introducing changes and helping incorporate and understand what is happening overall in the company.  Provides great volunteer and community involvement opportunities. Fantastic learning and career development resources are provided free of charge. Provide gym in the same building as work with membership discounts. Flexible working schedule allows to stay as needed to complete work.
cons: Found it difficult at times to connect on a personal level with employees but found group activities very helpful to get to know each other.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Unlimited income potential and provided a great work atmosphere and support.
cons: I found nothing negative that was worth talking about.

headline: AFA
pros: Little supervision, they let you design your own practice
cons: Too many to count.

headline: Okay, but you need to work for corporate or a growing financial practice
pros:
If you work on the franchise side of things, there can be good opportunities for you provided you are working within an ambitious practice.  Since you are essentially working in a small business, you get the flexibility that a small business can offer.

Most of the ratings will be wildly different from practice to practice.  I usually worked in friendly environments.
cons:
If you don't plan on being a financial advisor some day, there are very few opportunities for you within the franchisee world.  At the end of the day, financial advice is basically a sales job so if you don't have those skills, it will be tough to make a career doing office support.  

Pay and benefits will be based on how successful the practice is. They're not going to be as good as working for corporate.

I worked amongst 20-25 different practices.  Pretty high turnover rate in the low-level staff positions, usually due to people realizing they are pretty much maxed out after learning how to fill out the different new business forms and do the meeting prep.  If you aren't going to get licensed, you won't be doing a whole lot more than that.

Another thing I saw a lot of was a practice becoming comfortable with where they are at and not really growing much.  The advisor or their "marketing" staff need to be active in picking up new clients otherwise you end up with people who are fine with their incomes and work-life balance.  Once I started working full time out of school, I noticed that several of the advisors I worked for stopped coming to the office everyday as I was there to manage things.  "Working from home" and just showing up for client meetings doesn't really cut it.  Unfortunately, you have no way of knowing if you are going to be working in a practice that is going somewhere or one that is stagnant until you have put some time into it.

headline: Client Support
pros: always hiring new staff, nice facilities
cons: zero flexibility in phone service

headline: Client Service Associate
pros: Fun coworkers. Solid training and development.
cons: Can be political. Pay is average.

headline: Sales roles
pros: role straightforward, work hard get rewarded, good opportunity to get quarterly bonuses if put in the work, some training
cons: lack of diversity,  need more training, lack of female representation, hard mobility in between roles  and even divisions, lack of promotions

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Good company.  Worked in a franchise.  Real supervision and client reviews as opposed to Wall Street firms.  Definitely the tools to succeed and to give excellent client service.  Can charge for money management in addition to financial planning.  Good platform where clients benefit from advice.
cons: 1099 status is not advantageous to you, without benefits.  Didn't like the negotiable payout at the whim of the franchisee.  Corporate had their fingers in the pie too much so you would hear about various transactions -- which is good to correct the rare FA without integrity otherwise it's a hassle.

headline: Marketing Manager
pros: Great people, very organized, good benefits. People appreciate the work you do.
cons: Personalities can clash, pressure to produce is high

headline: Okay Experience
pros:
flexible schedule 
decent base pay
cons: too many happy hours for me

headline: Financial Planning Analyst
pros: Great learning experience. Very Ethical Firm that puts their clients best interest first. Work life balance is outstanding. The client service model is outstanding. Clients are very satisfied.
cons: Financial Planning system could be updated. It is very numbers based and you must have every aspect of the clients financial picture.

headline: Client Service Manager
pros: Great work environment. Small group of people that work together. Depending on your employer a lot of flexibility, which I have with mine (hours, taking time off etc)
cons: Since it is a Franchise I work for benefits are not as good as on a corporate level.

headline: Nice
pros: clean, secure, corporate conscious, community steward, company stock growth
cons: I resigned my position with Ameriprise due to poor leadership in my immediate supervisor.  This is not to say that there are other managers and corporate leaders who are very good within the organization; mine was poor.

headline: Over work employees
pros: Good benefits, good bonuses if their goals are met, some managers are good, good employee cafeteria. Training is sometimes efficient.
cons: Bad work life balance, they will fire you if you have 7 absences in a one year period. If your stats are low you will be written up. You are required to handle three to four different job functions at a time.

headline: Okish
pros: Great environment and great building
cons:
Little room for promotion
Little update

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Very good management and working atmosphere
cons: Financial Services is a very competitive business

headline: Great Place to Work!
pros:
Flexible
Opportunity for Growth
Challenging Work Environment
Good People to Work With
Good Benefits/Salary
cons:
Layers of Management
Corporate Speak
Nothing else I can think of

headline: Client Service Coordinator
pros: You learn valuable information, low overhead
cons: Your happiness depends on your advisory and their client base/work style

headline: Awesome Setup with a not so awesome team
pros: Decent Benefits , Stable growth, not a place for fast growers
cons: Management has made several hires from within the same family causing conflict of interest. A great team is effected by not so great leaders. Nepotism. Long hours without extra pay.

headline: Careless Management
pros: Ample resources, training, and support.
cons: Disorganized, no advancement, no reward for hard work, and upper management is unappreciative of staff.

headline: Stay away from technology positions.
pros: Good pay and benefits, flexible work schedule.
cons: The technology organization at Ameriprise is, by leaderships own admission, immature and flawed.  There is a great deal of mistrust and raillery between departments within IT that over the years has produced an environment more akin to a elementary class than a fortune 500 company.  Instead of working together as a whole for the good of the business each department see all others as rivals.  This leads to a daily infighting about problem ownership, project work, root cause analysis etc.  The problem is exacerbated by executive level micromanaging.  It’s standard practice that when an incident occurs leaders from the Sr. executive level down join bridge calls along with the engineers attempting to fix the issue.   These calls more often than not result in leaders literally screaming at each other and at the engineers attempting to fix the problem.   Almost all new employees have the same reaction “I can’t believe people treat each other that way”.   The company takes pride in completing annual employee engagement surveys which show these issues and technology also has the highest rate of turnover in the company.   To the credit of Ameriprise they have attempted to bring in consultants to help, and have sent leadership off to training to do trust falls and build relationships, but the efforts have not brought about any change.   While the pay and benefits are good I would not recommend any position within IT.

headline: Operations Engineer
pros: Good pay and a stable work environment
cons: Management is terrible, culture is terrible. Not unusual to hear yelling on calls between different groups. Company changes so slowly that it's hard to improve the company or make a difference.

headline: Good Start
pros: Great place to start a career. Unless you already have a book of buisness or a large network of individuals who do not currently have a FA, it is difficult to grow. But this is fairly standard when trying to become an FA.
cons: no real downside, if you build a good size book of buisness, I would recommend turning independent for better payout.

headline: Not For Me
pros: Everyone minds their own business.
cons: VERY micromanaged! Advisors don't know what they want. No guidance. Underpaid for doing lots. Always being pulled in different directions. CONSTANT meetings. How can I complete work if there are daily meetings???! Must read and sort advisor's email. Grow up and do that yourself!

headline: Positive experience
pros: Advisors are given a ton of support and all the tools to be successful. Plenty of professional development opportunities. Strong name in financial world.
cons: A lot of rules and regulations from corporate. Have to work with companies that are approved by Ameriprise, which can sometimes be frustrating.

headline: Risk Manager
pros: Excellent salary and endless opportunity for internal lateral or vertical job mobility.
cons: Hiring process is too lengthy and can discourage qualified candidates.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: None that I can think of at this time
cons: Commision based so you are totally dependent on selling product to customers. You are constantly being asked to sell certain investments for higher commision. The focus is on selling so the client becomes a second reason. It involves a lot of cold calling and getting people to talk to you. I absolutely hated it.

headline: Growth potential but highly micro-managed
pros: The company has a lot of perks available to its employees in terms of mentoring, networking opportunities, and career development  opportunities.
cons: I worked in a call center for brokerage service and the hours are set in stone, break times must be followed to the exact minute. They were pretty militant about that.  Micro-management was understandable but annoying.

headline: Client service coordinator
pros: Benefits, 1 week vacation, 2 weeks sick time
cons: Low salary, 401k match after a year

headline: Great Financial Planning Company
pros: A company with a strong leader. Its focus on financial planning leads to good advice given to its clients.
cons: The home office sometimes forgets the unique challenges of franchise offices in remote areas. They need to remember not all offices work the same or will give the same result.

headline: Manager
pros: Good executive leadership team and company is strong overall.  We have a good vision for the future
cons: Compensation is not equal. Managers don't support advancing in your current position. You have to change positions (even if you like your current role) to a different department if you want to grow at all.

headline: Manager
pros: Good executive leadership team and company is strong overall.  We have a good vision for the future
cons: Compensation is not equal. Managers don't support advancing in your current position. You have to change positions (even if you like your current role) to a different department if you want to grow at all.

headline: Financial planner
pros: Nice environment not much more to say. Some nice people to work with and some good managers. Ceo is good guy.
cons: Managers salaries are tied to sales force. If production drops they aren't happy. Many leads are old and clients with many complaints about previous planners. Advisor center is a mill and you don't get all that's available to clients for almost a year. Managers listen in on calls and can interject comments into your ear while speaking to clients. Clients can't hear manager but it can get distracting esp when the manager does not know anything about the client and makes recommendations that planner knows is not what the client wants or needs. If you don't make it to the client problems will arise and if you do you may lose the client.

headline: Sales and Service Representative
pros: Wonderful company.  Very supportive of their employees in helping them advance and build careers within the Ameriprise family
cons: In many areas they could think outside the box.

headline: Good Company
pros: Good level of frameworks and advance technolgical stack has been used
cons: Not good work life balance

headline: Client Service Manager
pros: Very flexible hours, easy going office, learn a lot about the market
cons: Can be boring at times, when the work load is small.

headline: Client Service Specialist
pros: Great place to start your career in the financial services industry. Not a big barrier to entry if you can convince them you are the right fit or right person for the job.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Team Leader
pros: Ameriprise is an employee friendly organization. I thoroughly enjoyed working with Ameriprise and would like to work again.
cons: Work Shift Timing and work life balance

headline: Auditor
pros: Flexible work schedule and good pay.
cons: Management was very sneeky and cut-throat.

headline: analyst
pros: flexible working schedule, good training
cons: relatively low pay, cold in minnesota

headline: Planning Assistant
pros: Provide many opportunities for entry level financial professionals to get financial services exposure
cons: Training programs are not as advanced relative to industry leaders

headline: Great company and good people
pros: Flexible, sound company and fiscally responsible. Benefits are fair and seem decent.
cons: Management top heavy, takes a long time for decisions to be made.

headline: 18 year employee
pros: People, benefit, customer and financial advisor are at the heart of everything. Moving quickly on new technology
cons:
Same as every other firm. 
Too many mtgs. 
The year end review process is tedious

headline: was financial advisor in franchise group
pros: reputable company, strong balance sheet, consumer awareness
cons: poor technology platform, low marketing support for senior advisors, high management turnover, high franchise fees, limited product platform

headline: Good Company
pros: Opportunity for growth, Positive attitude from senior advisors
cons: Not much guidance from senior advisors

headline: Working at this company is very challenging because I need to adjust to the requirements of three different managers.
pros: I have the opportunity to work on different projects every day so I can keep myself challenged, improve my skills and build new ones.
cons: The commute to the city is way too time consuming. I work only five hours a day but I spend close to three hours for commuting so I am not optimizing my time well

headline: Demanding role for front & back office work but attained valuable financial skills.
pros: Learned important financial and insurance processing. Company values are instilled to advisors with annual continued education.
cons: Overwhelming workload from calling clients to financial planning.

headline: Good company that's gotten better over the years
pros: Some pretty important employment considerations are taken seriously:  work-life balance, fair treatment and developing people, among others.  It's fertile ground for initiative taking, leader-minded folks.
cons: Like most larger companies, the pace of change can be slow, which is often frustrating.  Also, because people tend to stay with the company for longer than average tenures, it can be difficult in some departments to move up.

headline: Worked in Technology. Info Security team had people quitting as fast as possible.
pros: Compensation, nice offices at corporate, benefits are ok
cons: Micromanaging leadership, culture sucks big time in IT.  The CIO will be in front of the board explaining why IT people are quitting in droves soon!

headline: Director
pros: Paid vacation is really generous.
cons: There are none. I like working for Ameriprise.

headline: Administrative assistant NY
pros: Paying salary below the market. Don't work for them  unless you want to be a dishwasher and cleaning person for all office instead of doing job you were hired for.
cons: No room to grow. Bad company culture

headline: Great place to learn
pros: Anyone interested in the world of finance should start here.  You can be sponsored here for all brokerage licenses and move up fairly quickly.
cons: Office culture can be pretty serious at times depending on the advisor you work with.  All in all, no complaints. Pretty easy going.

headline: Political Nightmare
pros: Decent pay, great benefits, generous vacation policy, good bonuses (as long as the stock market is doing well).  Located downtown Mpls., a good place to be if you just want to "exist".
cons: Corporate Nepotism, poor leadership - micromanagement all the way up to the Executive Leadership Team , fear culture, chest beating rewarded, "you're lucky to work here" mantra, promotion of mediocrity, risk taking not encouraged, significant glass ceiling

headline: Don't drink the Koolaide
pros: If you are willing to put in time and effort; you can rise quickly or at the very minimum move laterally internally to many other positions.
cons: The claim to value culture and employee development, however I found that it a constant game of patting yourself on your back and demanding more money.

headline: Great place to work, unless you have an HR issue.
pros:
Good enough culture
Good opportunity for advancement
cons:
Low pay relative to competitors
If you're involved in project work prepare for LONG hours.
HR is a nightmare - The company is pretty good unless you need to contact Employee Relations for being mistreated. They will quickly go to work to protect the company and turn everything around on you. I know several people who have been pushed out and even fired after asking for help. If your boss is mistreating you just quietly find a new job and you should be fine.
Rating system, which determines merit increases and bonuses, is mostly a gauge of how much your boss likes you.
DO WHATEVER IT TAKES TO KEEP YOUR BOSS ON YOUR SIDE.

headline: Great culture, demanding work.
pros:
Competitive Salary
Great Benefits
Good Culture
Development Opportunities
Time-Off Policies
Company Values
Clear Vertical Movement Opportunities
Easy Horizontal Movement (Usually after 18 month commitment)
cons:
Highly Structured Environment (Could be a Pro for some)
Rigid Schedule

headline: Great Company
pros: Good corporate culture. Great office to work in.
cons: There are no cons to report

headline: OK
pros: Good training programs for advisors
cons: Too many egos to deal with

headline: Field office support staff.
pros: Great company to work for. Excellent benefits.
cons: Not much career growth outside Minneapolis.

headline: Intern
pros: Your income potential and career growth as a financial planner are in your hands if you are willing to put in the work.
cons: Financial Adviser was not very knowledgeable on investment theory and what are the main drivers of investment returns. He seemed more concerned about selling products than whether the product he was selling was actually a good product for the client.

headline: Ameriprise is stable
pros:
Stable work environment
Good people
Low pressure
Good balance
cons:
The culture and work environment can be very boring.
For a motivated individual, it can be very underwhelming.

headline: I was a financial planning assistant and a client services manager.
pros: Excellent opportunity to learn financial planning.  Ameriprise has impressive proprietary software for creating plans as well as client contact management.
cons: Each office vibe is dependent on the personality of the franchisee, and Home Office has very little impact on one's daily experience.  In my case,  the advisors I worked with were unpleasant, unprofessional, almost unstable, so it was like walking on eggshells every day.

headline: Completely Unethical
pros: Great benefits, decent technology, mediocre offices.
cons: Numerous unethical advisors, atrociously incompetent and unprofessional management, frequent disregard for clients and finra regulations.  Rampant theft by employees and numerous breaches of labor law.  Absolutely no accountability for reported human resources concerns even when documented.

headline: Good company depending on department
pros: Great benefits and yearly bonus
cons: Some departments have poor leadership. Company is not very innovative, very slow to make changes and adapt to innovatiion

headline: Any job is better than an AAC job
pros: They pay for your license. Sad to say that's it.
cons: The ameriprise advisor center is a joke. They decided a year ago to shove financial plans down all of their clients throats.  Most of the clientele of the aac don't warrant a financial plan. Its a stressful churn and burn call center focused on their profit not their advisors or god forbid their clients.  If you do what they ask ofyou you will go home feeling dissapointed in yourself at the end of the day. Unless you are really hard up avoid this place.

headline: Ahead of the curve
pros: Provide great technology support for advisors
cons: Compliance can be a pain sometimes. Limit available investments.

headline: Intern
pros: They were very Flexible with interns.
cons: The pay was not very sufficient

headline: Great Company
pros: Benefits, Salary, Gym, in-house bank, cafe
cons: None, I really like this company

headline: This was a phenomenal first internship experience.
pros: The company was filled with highly motivated and kind people. It is a great culture to surround yourself with.
cons: The skill level of some workers can be subpar at times.

headline: Tough position unless you have a large network.
pros: The position of Financial Advisor works for some people, but it is pretty difficult for others.
cons: When I joined the company I didn't have a large natural market.  Most of my leads came from lunch and learns and these people were more interested in a free lunch than anything else.  The work hours were unbelievable - most night I didn't get home until past 9 and worked on Saturdays.

headline: Great entry level job
pros: I was able to learn the way brokerage accounts worked in the financial industry.  I prepared and managed accounts for several clients and learned the trade.  If you're thinking about going into finance, I'd definitely start here and branch out later.  Learn the ropes and then fly.  Ameriprise is very organized.  Good potential to grow since they sponsor your exams too.
cons: Pretty square job and becomes monotonous after awhile.  Then again, I'm biased because I'm artistic and need to be in a field where I'm allowed to think creatively.

headline: Working at Ameriprise
pros: Good support from the home office, decent benefits
cons: Too rigid in  their methodology, pushing expensive financial plans and proprietary products.

headline: best company hands down to work for
pros: great compensation and benefits
cons: i do not have any

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Fee Based Platform, long list of approved products, national marketing campaigns and clean and professional client facing web presence.
cons: Work life balance, Fees for Associates Financial Advisors AFA's and Para Planners.

headline: Good company that cares about it's employees
pros: Company seems to generally care about it's employees, offers a lot of PTO days (plus the ability to buy more), great benefits, etc.
cons: For lack of a better way to describe it, the atmosphere at the company can be very stuffy.  Depending on the organization you are a part of they don't do a good enough job keeping salaries competitive and end up losing good talent.

headline: I became licensed and went through their vetting process as a financial advisor.
pros: The team dynamic was good with excellent sales training and educational meetings.
cons: Long hours, cold calling and high levels of output required.

headline: Good company if you know the right people
pros: The company has Benefits, Work LIfe balance, Compensation, Senior management, and the Coworkers are really energetic and love their jobs.
cons:
Slow growth
Favorites played
Location, parking is expensive

headline: Great company
pros: Growth and development.  Good management, benefits and yearly bonus. Annual merit increase. Tons of recognition
cons: 30 minute lunches. occurrences, low cubicles, the company is great and long lasting

headline: Paraplanner
pros: Each office usually independent so salary, responsibilities, and hours will each be different.
cons: No real complaints about the office I worked in

headline: Nice place to work
pros: Management is very friendly at any step. Good training, learn more about financial planning and investment strategies, value of employee, crystal clear HR policies, very good life balance.
cons: No Indian holidays, most of team work at night shift.

headline: Ameriprise Financial has a small company feel with a large company's opportunities.
pros: They are loyal to their employees. Most managers are encouraged to help their employees develop. New opportunities are abundant.
cons: Does not put you in the best position to negotiate salary bumps.

headline: Good Company - Lots of Change
pros:
I was fortunate to work on several teams where collaboration was highly valued, autonomy was encouraged, and our team members were treated like adults instead of employees.

The environment was business casual, and my leaders generally had a good open-door policy.
cons:
Reorganizations were frequent (often internally referred to as Spring Cleaning and Fall Cleaning), so as changes would start there was always concern about whether 'your' job would be affected. Communications surrounding change was sometimes lacking, so there would be unanswered questions as to the thought process behind the changes.

The benefits package was fair, but the company requires employees to save and use their personal PTO for days when the corporate office is closed (market holidays). PTO does not carry over, but sick days do. That being said, sick days were reduced from six to four in 2008 or 2009. The stated reason was corporate research indicated people only used an average of four sick days per year - but they did not offer any balance to the removal of the two extra days (i.e. two extra PTO days), just took them away.

headline: Great employer
pros: Great benefits, the company  truly  cares about its employees. Unbelievable 401k company contributions. Management is always available to listen for suggestions  or creative feedback
cons: Some long hours at times, but the pros far out weight the cons. It does take awhile to get built up to maximum  PTO hours.

headline: I worked part time as a financial services intern in Hartford during my fall semester of my junior year of college.
pros: Ameriprise has a very positive and friendly working environment.  I was the only intern there and everyone else was either a financial advisor or an assistant, but I always felt like I was part of the team.  I used morning star on a regular basis and learned a lot about mutual funds.
cons: My experience of the semester long internship at Ameriprise was that after the first two weeks work was very stagnant.  I was not able to contribute more to the organization nor was a I given a set of different tasks for me to take away from.  I felt as though I was more of an assistant position, which was frustrating because I was not getting paid.

headline: Great people, great opportunities--once you're inside
pros:
Compensation is at or above market rate.
Amazing training program for entry-level financial advisors.
Cutting edge trading platform.
cons:
Metrics constantly change--corporate initiatives feel like whack-a-mole.
Absent management.
Little collaboration between departments.

headline: Good company with continuous growth.
pros: Growing company provides a great environment to be a part of. Services we provide are invaluable to clients. I foresee this being a service that people will seek out and continue to utilize for years to come and therefore a company that will continue to evolve and grow.
cons: Male dominated work environment and little diversity overall. Unless you live near headquarters in Minneapolis, growth within the company and "moving up the corporate ladder" is difficult to do as a result of limited roles within the field.

headline: Pros and cons
pros: Good work life balance.  Good exposure to finance leadership.
cons: Depending on area the opportunities and path for promotion were unclear.  Despite the exposure to senior leadership there appeared to be little upside.

headline: Sales, not advise
pros: Decent pay when you are in your 20s
cons: It's a sales organization masked by advice.  Advisors more concerned with heir commissions and maintaining payout than doing what is best for client

headline: Great internship opportunity if you want to work there
pros: The best part about this internship was truly experiencing every aspect of a corporate environment. You will gain a lot of skills. Everyone I spoke to seemed nice and a few wanted to help me advance if I planned on working there. The hours were relatively flexible, but if you are doing the internship for credit, be firm about your hours. I was able to attend many networking opportunities, which I did not have to pay for. Overall, if this is a company you wish to work for, work hard, and you will be noticed.
cons: I did not receive any compensation, but did receive college credit. The internship was not enjoyable in the sense that I spent more time watching than doing. I was also told that learning experiences were not ok, which made me hesitant to make any errors. My hours, while flexible, were longer that my credit called for. I was fine with this, but towards the end of the day, the hours dragged as there was little to do. I was very proactive with taking on tasks, but the environment I worked for didn't require an enormous need for an extra hand.

headline: Super Company
pros: I have been with this company for 8 years! They have really good benefits. They have great training and opportunities and recognition. In my experiences, I have had great teachers and are willing to help me reach my goals.
cons: The salary levels should be better as well as bonuses. It would be nice to see an improvement especially if you have given 5, 10 or more years.

headline: Strong management, but culture of micromanagement
pros:
Smart management team has company going in right direction
Good benefits package
Ethical company with mission of helping people feel more financially secure
cons: Culture of micromanagement throughout the organization

headline: Strong management, but culture of micromanagement
pros:
Smart management team has company going in right direction
Good benefits package
Ethical company with mission of helping people feel more financially secure
cons: Culture of micromanagement throughout the organization

headline: Intern
pros: people were enjoyable to work with, very flexible, very understanding, was able to learn the basics of investing and analyzing client portfolios
cons: too small, not enough to give me

headline: Good culture, flexible schedule once build your book of business
pros: Flexible schedule. Good support from corporate.
cons: Takes time to get a strong book of business to have a profitable practice.

headline: Your Mileage May Vary Dependent on What Franchise You're In--Associate Financial Advisor
pros:
Every franchise is it's own little world, so some are wonderful and can help you grow, but some are a living nightmare.
If you land in one of the former, you can help each other to succeed and have your own practice, even as part of a team.  This allows for growth and flexibility.
cons: There is really no supervision of franchises in terms of how they run their practice.   It appears that they don't care if an advisor abuses his associates or employees, so long as he makes money.  No accountability to stand behind promises to associates brought in.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: I really enjoyed working here. My boss believed in me and pushed me beyond my limits helping me grow quickly.
cons: Low ceiling. Unless you go into an advisor role, there is only so much growing you could do.

headline: Service Coach
pros:
Great benefits. Cultural diversity and respect. Leadership that seems to care about employees.
Suppotive of work/life balance.
Senior leaders model integrity and respect.
cons: Often too much work to do. New initiatives and processes can sometimes be  rolled out before engaging necessary key stake holders. With scrambling to fix problems that had not been anticipated. Probably a normal corporate problem

headline: Ameriprise Financial
pros:
Fast paced environment.
Travel often doing sales presentations and some one on one meetings.
Lots of Autonomy to drive your results to hit company goals initiatives
Focused on the client
cons:
Not a common role in the industry so hard to explain to people from the outside.
Low Compensation relative to similar positions
You can't ever be doing enough to do a good job
Rules, Regulations and vision continue to change every three years.

headline: Good Company
pros: Great training and industry experience
cons: Can be difficult to balance objectives

headline: IT is run by micro managment
pros: good year end bonus and lots of benefits perks, good individual contributors
cons: IT had no respect for peoples personal life, you are treated like a 10 year old, lack of trust and toxic culture

headline: Solid company
pros: Benefits and salary are good.  Hardly lay off.
cons: Too conservative to performance manage out the bad talent.

headline: Registered Staff for Franchisee (Paraplanner)
pros: Don't have to deal with a sterile corporate culture, lot's of flexibility. Financial planning is at the core of what we do so I feel like we are aligned with the clients best interest and not here to merely make money off pushing product that may not be in the clients best interest. Good place to get experience, good place to be a lead/franchise advisor. High payouts
cons:
Health benefits are not mandatory with franchise owners, I currently pay for all my own health benefits. All franchise owners are different but they are essentially small business owners and can run their practice how ever they want.  Ameriprise, on the franchise and corporate side, as a whole pays their staff less than average compared to other firms. This came straight from one of the Ameriprise leaders at a top performers conference in La Quinta. 
Hard to grow to an advisor role from registered staff, in general advisors want to hire experienced advisors with a small book of business. For that reason I'm leaving to be an advisor at another firm (Schwab). Offer already accepted,

headline: Operations
pros: The people are great
cons: No room for advancement

headline: Good company
pros: Good company values, focus on financial planning and putting clients first.
cons: Technology has been lagging but improving recently

headline: Is going to be very office specific but my person experience was wonderful
pros: There is a a lot of flexibility to make of it what you want to.  The people your working with really make the experience.  I was lucky enough to work with a small team of intelligent, hard working professionals and respected each other and communicated well.
cons: The technology and support from headquarters could use a lot of improvement.  Often updates, software bugs and other issues would be the biggest hindrance to productivity.

headline: Ameriprise
pros: Good benefits, great stated mission, lots of great employees
cons: staff are not valued and have no control over who they work with. Leadership does not encourage great staff and rather works against them to protect their own jobs.

headline: Ameriprise
pros: Emphasis on development and learning
cons: some leaders are not good people leaders

headline: Good company to work for, nice people
pros: Good salary qualitative work you will get a chance to work with industry experts
cons: Less chances of growth in this company

headline: Process over skill
pros: Ameriprise values processes that can make the company succeed.
cons: The process are sometimes too rigid to allow for innovation.

headline: Great Company!
pros: After 16 month commitment employees can look for promotions within company. Great career growth
cons: I do not have anything negative

headline: Great Company
pros:
Flex time
Nice co-workers
Great benefits
Company Values
Work-life balance
cons: They dont give promotions, even if you work your butt off to get them

headline: OK experience
pros: They provide you with a wide variety of tools to work with and gain experience using.  Wide range of products and services are offered to clients.
cons: Not very supportive for someone who is young and trying to start off as a Financial Advisor.  They focus more on the established advisor.

headline: Can be a good place to work
pros: Competitive pay and benefits. Relatively good corporate culture.
cons: No meritocracy, unfriendly to older workers, tough to find a good leader

headline: Great Company and Opportunity. Management must improve Division's direction.
pros:
- Great place to work if you are starting out in the business.  
- Provided all new employees with continuous training.  (Heard it has changed from colleagues who are still there, 10/14)
- Co-workers worked hard to achieve their goals, and were helpful when you experienced difficulties.
- Many opportunities to work in different parts of the company, if you choose to.
cons:
Want to state that this is not a Branch office.  This was an inside sales job in the corporate building.  Keep that in mind when reading about my experience:
- Too much turnover.  
- People were leaving or being let go, quicker than hiring allowed.  
- Quality of advice may have suffered because of that, which hurt brand's reputation.
- Payouts do not reflect that of industry
-

headline: Stagnant
pros: Lots of good, smart people scattered through the company who  care about the clients and the firm
cons: Operating model is antiquated. No support for innovation or growth. Csuite involved in every little decision. Marketing used to be great, now it reports to finance and is only seen as an opportunity to cut not an engine to grow. Leaders spend all their time focused on beating each other, none thinking about beating the competition. Some departments can be tough for women.

headline: just a job
pros: benefits, coworkers, I honestly cannot think of anything else.
cons: be very careful of statements made by recruiters. I left a decent paying job for this job when the recruiter implied people  bonused much more than what they currently pay (which is a joke, considering how profitable they are). The training for some departments is absolutely horrible, with little to no support once you begin taking calls. Staffing levels were almost always low when I was there, forcing people to take more and more work.  The work itself sucks. A typical day involves listening to some idiot complain about back office screw ups (which happen quite often), paperwork not being processed on time, bad information provided by associates, etc. Speaking of screw ups, there is little to no accountability for mistakes made. You can provide bad information and chances are you will not hear about it. Advisors simply call in multiple times until they get the answer they want to hear. Some coaches and leaders are a joke, and take advantage of their positions, yet no one seems to care. I see plenty of chit chatting between some coaches and leaders when there are calls in queue waiting for 15 to 20 minutes on hold. The communication between departments is absolutely horrible. It is not uncommon to get some sarcastic response from a frustrated processor when you send an email asking for help. I've never seen such a high turn over rate until i started working here. I've sat next to people who show up to work in the morning, get their belongings and simply just walk out. 4 people remain out of the 12 that started in my department last year. Only one or two people actually put in their two week notice, the rest just walked out. Very little engagement, very little room for advancement. I could go on and on......

headline: Great place for those who are content to settle.
pros: Decent salary, benefits, and PTO.
cons: Way too political and Minnesota passive-aggressive

headline: Ameriprise corporate
pros: engaged workforce, high level of integrity and adherence to regulations
cons: low pay for the marketplace/region

headline: Fairly good company to work for
pros: Solid company, ok pay, ok bonus
cons: some leaders are horrible to work with

headline: A great place to work
pros: A multifaceted environment that allows for learning many different things.
cons: Juggling expenses and cost savings with staffing and productivity needs.

headline: Ameriprise: Hitting Its Stride Nicely
pros: I've worked for the company for 15 years in the Home Office.  Most of my direct leaders (over a dozen of them by now) have been very good, and all have been reasonable to work for.   My positions have afforded me good work/life balance and typically a 40-45 hour week, occasionally 50 hours. Corporate culture is excellent  I'd say, with a heavy focus on volunteering/contributing to charitable organizations.  Various employee groups/clubs feed employee interests and build a sense of community.  The best part is the excellent senior leaders (no this is not a paid review-really).  Since Ameriprise spun off from American Express 6 years ago, I have never had more confidence in the company, its direction, or its senior leadership. (I work a professional, but non-leadership job.)  The company continues to execute very well against its strategy and leaders are hard working, thoughtful and anxious to make Ameriprise successful and a great place to work.  I have met a lot of friends here over the years and feel comfortable that there is a job here for me for many years if I want it and keep working hard. That's a great feeling.
cons: It's a large corporation and sometimes the focus of work can be very tight.  There are many roles and functions and many can be interesting and challenging while others are much less so.  You reap what you sow and what your skills and abilities allow for, I suppose.

headline: Company
pros: Ok Company to work for
cons: None that i can think of

headline: IT at Ameriprise
pros: If you get in with the right manager, you can advance fairly quickly. Salary is average, but bonuses are good. 401k match at 5% is average, which is a little ironic for a financial advising firm. Other benefits are below average. The work environment is fine, typical for a Fortune 500.
cons: There are a lot of politics here. There's less of a focus on technology. Most Ameriprise IT employees are not technical, resulting in those that are having inflated egos. Vendors tend to have their way. Work-life balance is generally good, with occasional periods of additional effort expected. I'm not sure of the numbers, but turnover seems high.

headline: Satisfying organization in which to contribute and accumulate accomplishments
pros: Ameriprise supports a culture of collaboration, informal networking and due diligence to advance clients' best interests. There is a ready willingness to listen to new ideas, incorporate proven innovations from leading practices and evaluate continuous improvement efforts against measurable performance goals and objectives.
cons: Incorporating networking into your daily job is essential, and challenging due to ongoing work loads, given the long-term relationships that drive operational activities across lines of business.

headline: Potential, Too Micromanaged
pros: People and atmosphere was very friendly, facilities and location were nice, absolutely zero take-home work.
cons: Intense to-the-minute micromanagement of phone schedules, ridiculous sick days policy (got put on probation for using all of my sick days, no extra ones, one year), cliques were very noticeable and exclusive.  They will tell you that phones are the number one way to start in the company and move upwards, but very few people actually get the opportunity for that.

headline: Good organization, not so great people
pros: Great organization, it has some highly motivated people, awesome employee engagement, facilities are good too with cab, food, play areas, festivities etc.
cons: the pay structure is cumbersome, the long term deferred bonus is something which does not work for everyone and you actually end up leaving your earned money with the company when you leave the job. The growth prospects are good but then a lot depends on the self motivation of individual rather than the leaders. Limited scope for personal growth.

headline: Targeted Career Changer
pros: One of the best training programs available.  Decent Salary first year at $45,000 then to 33,000 year 2 and 15,000 year 3 if goals met prior years.
cons: It takes much longer to establish your business than indicated during interview.  Mentors require approximately 20% of your commissions, which is not disclosed initially.  You won't have a life the first 3-5 years.

headline: Very good
pros: Good culture intimate a lot of support
cons: Micro managed by too many people

headline: Career Treadmill-- it can be fun!
pros: Great benefits. Once you're in, you're in for life. Hard to leave a nice company. VERY friendly people. Most of my friends in my social circle are people I met at AMP. Wonderful stock price. They truly care about the employees. Lots of ways to voice feedback. Onsite gym & cafeteria were stellar. I stayed because I had so many good friends.
cons: Difficult to get promoted beyond Band 30-35. Can get stuck in a rut easily. Lots of boondoggle work in some departments. Lots of bureaucracy for changes. People are conditioned to do the same thing over and over again.

headline: It's hard, but so worth it!
pros: The benefits are outstanding and begin the day you begin.  I became sick during my training and was able to use my paid time off to take off an see a doctor! Who does that?  When I began my credit was garbage and they still gave me their creditcard with a $500 limit!  Also, they pay you your regular salary during training! BOOM!
cons: Many positions require licensing and they are not easy to obtain.  I practically slept through the real estate exam and passed it while everyone around me was pulling their hair out.  These securities exams, on the other hand, no dice!  Hardest test I've ever endured.  I'd do it again for another chance to work for them. I only failed by 3 points!

headline: felt undervalued most of the time
pros: I enjoyed the people a lot. I liked my boss because he was very caring and took us all out to events that he threw for his clients. good for entry level I suppose.
cons: Did not feel valued at all. Did mundane tasks, even though we were promised to be trained in performing certain tasks. There isn't much room for growth. Stuck doing the same task that a monkey can do. If you're not the advisor, then you are nothing.

headline: Mediocre
pros: Decent place to start out of school.
cons: Pay is lower than a warehouse job. Ed Jones pays for you to study and train, Ameriprise private franchises will work you like a dog.

headline: Advisor
pros: Solid company, fun work atmosphere
cons: Long hours, no work life balance

headline: One of the best company in Asset Management Industry
pros: Work Culture,Infrastructure,Good paymasters,Good cab and food facility,Approachable Superiors
cons: Nothing as such as the experience was very satisfactory

headline: Very difficult to get going
pros: The sales training is second to none and they provide opportunities for institutional advancement if you excess expectations.
cons: They need a better compensation structure because advisors are forced to us commission-based products to keep up with quotas. They don't do what is best for the client, which creates and negative public image.

headline: It was not a very good experience.
pros: Learn the basics of financial planning and do a lot of financial plans. It works best in theory but in practice you cannot make any amount of decent money doing plans. Salary of $ 36k to $ 39k is not at all appropriate to do business of financial planning.Good work culture and leadership but it is bent to give more opportunities to successful advisors only.
cons:
