Training is good but again you are giving lots of time doing financial plans ( loss leader) and if you do not realize you may spend 2 to 3 years not getting paid or having any meaningful traction.Focus on insurance and managed money later. .....too much focus on disability insurance.....
I would prefer to manage and gear myself to be an asset gatherer with AUM to sustain some business.....You are starving and cannot continue doing financial plans. As it is not the plans but what they lead to is important

headline: Great Opportunity
pros: Great leadership training opportunity. Nice people to work with. Benefits are strong.
cons: So many people stay with the company for the entire duration of their careers making it difficult to move up.

headline: Franchise of Ameriprise
pros: Franchises have the freedom & flexibility to create our own client service model, so each franchise will be different. If looking at joining a franchise, be sure to find one that is consistent with your professional goals & values. Team based working environment. Managing partners provide professional guidance.
cons: Weekly technology issues, which was a corporate issue & not the franchise. Within franchises there can be conflicting messages regarding employee roles & responsibilities.

headline: Limited growth for sales support staff. Good old boys club and greedy advidors. Stay away!
pros: 40 hour work week. Decent 401k match if you last 5 years. Decent medical benefits. Thats about it.
cons: Pay is a joke. Advisors on P1 (Corporate) side greedy as heck. No room for growth, no pay for performance, no bonuses for sales support staff, no training in field, nobody cares about your career. Leadership is a joke. The worst I've seen. HR/Recruiters in the field are also pathological liars, so dont listen to anything they say.

headline: Working for Ameriprise was my first professional job out of college
pros: Good entry level opportunity to learn skills and get series 7 and 66 while being paid, pay was decent for the job you do, something good to put on your resume when you're right out of school. It's a very good company I just have  a negative experience with this particular franchise office.
cons: worked in a very small office.. 3 people including myself, my boss was creepy for lack of better terms and could get away with inappropriate conversation topics in such a small office; at will employment- meaning you can be fired for anything. If working for this company work for corporate office or a larger practice

headline: Good company to work for.
pros: Great training programs for systems and customer service from the home office.  In the 21st century with their technology, many clients are tech savvy and appreciate this.
cons: I worked in a branch and therefore was never able to visit the home office in MN.  Would have liked to had assigned people in the home office that took care of our branch as opposed to getting a new person every time we had to call for assistance.

headline: Very strong company financially
pros: Benefits are outstanding.
cons: Company has strong ethical values, and makes certain these core values are exhibited in employees

headline: The best company to work for.
pros: good pay, great management team to work for. Ameriprise has an amazing culture in regards to there environment. It is a company with outstanding comradery and a team togetherness that I've never felt from any other company.
cons: none great company absolutely no compliance thus far.

headline: Excellent company to work for
pros: Excellent company to work for
cons: sometimes feel isolated, and disconnected

headline: Fair
pros: Good benefits.  Access to lots of training resources, HR is quick to deal with, and technology is very up to date.  There are good measuring sticks and senior leaders are very helpful and great people.
cons: Matrix management can be a little confusing and frustrating at times.  As much as the senior leaders are great people, the number of them that you report to can be frustrating since not everyone's goals are always in line.

headline: The company is trying to improve shareholder value by charging advisors increased fees and technology costs.
pros: Company has few restrictions on investment choices. Payouts seem better than most firms. Meetings and travel are held to a minimum. Field supervision is not repressive and has improved. Improving technology, but charging for most types of back room assistance.
cons: Saddled with non-responsive, ineffective, uneducated field supervision initially...has been replaced, Initial training was non-existent, CEO only cares about company stock performance (Bonus tied to this no doubt).

headline: Ameriprise doesn't value their employees
pros: The benefits were the best part of the job.
cons: No work-life balance - expect 60+ hours a week to meet goals.  Toxic / hostile work environment - finger pointing, lying and back stabbing to defect attention from real issues.  Advancement based on ability to quote meaningless political-speak rather than results.  Technology leadership believes they can run the business better than the business units.  Technology department acts like they are a profit center - charging business units more than actual labor rate to build a slush fund to execute their own projects without business approval, often times to the detriment of the business.  Executive leadership blinded by small details and not seeing the big picture - i.e., offshore labor costs are 30% cheaper than onshore, but they don't want to hear that it take twice as many offshore resources and takes twice as long to complete a task.  Executive leaderships has only two strategies to increase revenues - replace older employees with younger cheaper employees, and buy other more successful firms.

headline: IF you want to rest then enjoy Ameriprise
pros:
1. Grand old US company
2. Good pay master
cons:
1. Very slow in work pace
2. Turning out to be a government organization

headline: Good place to work
pros: A great variety of tasks and responsibilities each day, great work/life balance, a very professional work environment,  some training opportunities, and access to great research and trading platform.
cons: Limited career advancement, few benefits, a sales company- so if you don't like sales this career/company is not for you. Ameriprise always seems to be a few steps behind regarding technology.

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: the vision and mission of financial planning is important to the people who work there and they believe they are adding value to the community.
cons: No assistance with growing your book of business.  There is more focus on getting books quickly with little to no guidance.

headline: Great environment. Great place to start out for college grads. Little room for growth but plenty of exit opportunities.
pros: Has a nice relaxed environment. Great place for recent grads. Stress is low depending on your position. Plenty of exit opportunities.
cons: Very little room for growth. Lots of potential for lateral movement but not vertical movement.

headline: Great environment. Great place to start out for college grads. Little room for growth but plenty of exit opportunities.
pros: Has a nice relaxed environment. Great place for recent grads. Stress is low depending on your position. Plenty of exit opportunities.
cons: Very little room for growth. Lots of potential for lateral movement but not vertical movement.

headline: Run, Run Away as Fast as You Can
pros: The people are generally Minnesota Nice.
cons:
- This company is a business cycle behind, and out of touch with the financial services environment as a whole.
- Too many "home grown" staff who don't understand how much they really don't know.
- Run by a clique- the pretty girl from high school in full force.  You'll never be promoted unless you play the back stabbing political BS.  Single, straight males need not apply.
- All the managers are "leaders".  Statistically, this is an impossibility resulting in a complete joke.
- Corporate slogans and BS everywhere on the walls.  How about you spend some time fixing the problems instead of pushing the branding down everyone's throat?
- Management and decision by committee.  No accountability what so ever, unless they want to get rid of you of course.

headline: Workplace Environment
pros: Good Pay based upon pay bands
cons: Difficult workplace environments for married individuals as affairs are common place between wholesalers and advisors.

headline: Stable job, less of office politics, good place to work, good salary
pros:
Good place to work
Decent facilities
Stable company
Good rewards and recognition program
cons:
Little emphasis on training and development
More emphasis on cost control
Too much dependence on onshore partners
Mediocrity is a norm

headline: Great Experience at a small franchise
pros: I worked for a small franchise, and the owners were amazing. The company genuinely seems to care about clients, and doesn't push products just to get commission.
cons: small team = more work, but it was rewarding. When it came to marketing, sometimes it was hard to be creative within the corporate guidelines.

headline: AAC They are clueless....not in touch with reality.VERY LOW PAY !
pros: Help with getting licences...p/c correct and nice co workers...
cons: Pay changes EVERY COUPLE OF MONTHS and the elimination of commission and over time. Expected to work 50-60 hours a week.Bonus are very subjective to mangers discretion and your team mates performance which most are clueless..micro managed to death.Stress level is unbearable cramming financial plans down poor client throats is main focus and not for clients true needs.Turn over is tremendous..Managers are running it like a highschool  .Watching your conversations and lunch breaks/bathroom...Upper management is down right oppressive,  keeps salespeople in the dark and belittle them when you ask questions such as pay structure or goals

headline: Don't do it.
pros: Dental plan has allow 4 cleanings/year
cons: Clique-y/Gossip-y company, no work life balance, senior management unaware of mid-level Director level actions, coming/goings. Company promotes only those that management likes versus work effort. Admins are promoted to Dir/Manager positions to give weather reports. Terrible pay(depends who one works for), mediocre benefits, poor work environment, can be loud, disturbing. If one is a secretary, they will do great.

headline: Fight or Flight.
pros: The food was exceptional in the cafeteria. The benefits were superb. Associates were friendly and was able to make meaningful connections.
cons: My training group was not even trained properly. The people in leadership roles were horrible leaders  and unwilling to lend any type of helpful direction.

headline: Avoid!
pros: Ability to be your own boss in the franchise channel.
cons: The senior level leadership are more concerned with their paychecks and the shareholders than they are yours. There is direct conflict between their employee and franchise channels that make no sense and make it difficult to become a franchisee.

headline: Neutral
pros: Good place to find an entry level position or begin your career
cons: Difficult to develop in the long term

headline: Poor Management
pros: I was able to learn about the financial services industry without having had the experience in the past.  I enjoyed the opportunity to support financial advisors in complying with state and federal laws and regulations.  Ameriprise was doing a very good job of following these laws and regulations.  I felt good to be working with an institution that played by the rules in the financial sector.  My salary increased by at least 3% each year and each year I earned a bonus.  Benefits such as health insurance and the amount of personal day accrual were better than average.
cons: Employees only receive 4 sick days a year and each separate absense was counted as an occurance.  Being over 12 minutes to 50 minutes late would result in a 1/2 occurance and over 50 minutes as a full occurance regardless of the reason.  Five occurances would result in a verbal warning and 6 would result in a written warning.  More than 6 would result I'm termination. This policy was for most of the employees but there were favorite employees in the same position I was in that got treated differently.  The way that the policy was implemented across the organization depended on which team leader you had.  My team leader used the policy to intimidate those people she did not like.  Upper management was given information from various employees but did nothing or told the team leader who was responsible leading to retaliation.  The management was weak and certain employees were able to dominate who didn't necessarily have the best imtereats of the company in mind.  These employees were allowed to intimidate the weaker employees and there were many cliques and in my experience one bully who was not a supervisor.  I loved my job but the environment was too toxic.

headline: Great place to start your Financial Planning Career.
pros: Fortune 500 company with over 100 years experience and the most CFPs in the industry. Investing large sums in advertising and latest technology. Great training in latests producs and services as well as how to manage your own financial planning practice. You create equity in your business which you may be able to sell at a future stage.
cons: While improving and expanding its offerings of 3rd party insurance & annuities products, still has a limited range of vehicles in these areas. Very little marketing help. Not producing warm leads for advisors to call. To get top payout rate, you have to produce an insane amount of GDC and the annual "Grid" benchmarks are always moving higher. There is oviously an advisor income squeeze going on.

headline: Good place to work and enjoy at the same time
pros:
People are good. 
Annual bonus gets really good over time.
cons: Work-life balance could be improved by moving afternoon shifts to morning.

headline: Be very very careful
pros: Big company, people form a bond, a lot of training, opportunities to advance if you fit their mold. Can get paid. Can work different parts of business. There are a lot of people at the office.
cons: I had a horrible experience overall. I felt discriminated against. I was lied to extensively. Leadership doesn't care about developing you they are only looking to exploit you. Reminded me way too much of high school . Leaders are young and don't have experience outside of Ameriprise

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Company helps corporate channel advisors grow their business by providing marketing $ for client and prospect events/seminars. Good firm for learning how to become a financial planner. The stock has done extremely well, thank you Mr. Cracchiolo.
cons: Sales support within the office is spread thin and reduced access to quality home office sales support puts a greater onus on the FA to handle menial tasks and service issues.  On the plus side, cost cutting contributed to the increased share price.  This is first and foremost a financial planning based firm and insurance sales are strongly and consistently encouraged. If you want to build or run your business at a more traditional financial advisor/brokerage firm, look elsewhere (put this in the PRO column if you want to run an insurance based financial planning practice, but consider the franchise channel for a higher net payout).

headline: Not going in a good direction
pros: Very good benefits, vacation allotments, 401(k), etc. Cooperative and friendly workplace for the most part. Lots of freedom to move around within the organization, get new experiences and job skills.
cons: The company is operating in a less transparent way than they used to. No one knows when employees leave the company or move to a different department. All of that is held very close. One day you have a good contact in another area and the next day the cubicle is empty. Not good for morale.

headline: Great Place to work, strong room to grow, nice corporate culture
pros:
- Many opportunities for growth within the home office
- Great benefits and time off 
- Nice 401k matching program
- Good work life balance culture within the company
- The company rewards performance, bonuses at most job levels.
cons: - High management turnover & multiple reorganizations made the work environment unnecessarily stress-full at times.

headline: Bureaucratic nightmare, no employee engagement
pros: Someday this company will go under
cons: Low compensation compared to competitors, little to no employee engagement or outreach

headline: Pressure cooker environment
pros: Good pay. Comfortable office. Good food in cafeteria.
cons: Evenings and weekends are required to keep up. Many of the corporate RP II's are divorced or single.

headline: Financial Planning and Advisory Service
pros: Fortune 500 in the US
cons: Low future prospects in India

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Pretty good training, and they did a good job of guiding you through the entire licensing process.  Their expectations were clear and they did a good job of giving you the tools needed to be successful.
cons: Long hours with little pay.  You have to sell insurance products to make any money.  I felt that I had to sell products to people that they shouldn't be buying in order to meet sales goals and make any money.  I didn't feel like a financial advisor, I felt like an insurance salesman.  My entire time there felt a little unethical.  You have to charge people for your advice that other companies give for free.  I would never work there again, hated it, and my time there almost earned me a divorce.

headline: Working hard to branch out
pros: great benefits, work and life balance is respected for the most part (vacations and sick time are sacred), they are really trying to develop their brokerage area, most managers are down to earth and have an open door policy.
cons: They claim to be different from wire houses, but they enable disrespectful behavior from successful advisors; upper management is afraid of top producers.  Lack of brokerage experience allows them to turn the other cheek with common compliance issues.

headline: Work hard, and the rewards will come.
pros: Lots of thought and energy from Corporate folks is pushed down to FAs; support is available for those that are seen working hard. You can usually find an expert/resource with whatever you are facing to help out clients. Advisors that want to start offering Financal Planning (the Ameriprise way) will find LOTS of support.
cons: The "Leadership" at the regional level and above have HUGE egos.... not sure why. The back office compliance people are a real pain in the butt, not what anyone would refer to as "helpful". The SF office looses, then gains, a new Branch Manager each year.

headline: Training Robots
pros: Well established training program and supportive team members.
cons: Training all employees like robots left no room for individualism. What I mean is that each of us in the training program were taught one way to talk, walk, and dress. I was not a fan.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: I've worked for Ameriprise for 10+ years. The culture is fantastic. The company focuses on teamwork, excellence, and customer service. I think it's a great place to work.
cons: I can't think of any cons. I've been happy.

headline: A company with lots of great resources
pros: There are a lot of resources available to you to manage your business and learn.  The internal department is very helpful and supportive to give you the answers you need.  If there's a answer someone can't answer for you, be it a highly compensated executive looking for help to most tax-efficiently receive his compensation or just trying to troubleshoot technology, you're going to get help towards obtaining the answer.
cons: There really isn't a straightforward training program even though the training resources are great.  So, it is more about yourself being able to manage yourself and take initiative for your own success.  Though, that's not to say there aren't mentors and others there to support you.  There's a lot of them.

headline: Financial Advisor Assistant
pros:
-Opportunities to grow
-Advisors are friendly and encouraging
-Ability to establish great mentor relationships
-Learning the ins and outs to a financial practice
-Training services and Independent work
cons:
-A lot of  deal of busy office work
-Ease of moving within the company may take time
-Comfortability contacting clients over phone

headline: Good Organization to work for
pros:
Work Life balance is good
Compensation structure is good
Management is helpful and open to suggestions
cons: Personal growth is too dependent on Line Manager and the skip levels are just namesake

headline: Good job- not always a career option- Ambitious beware!
pros: Established company, Easy-to-use tools, Plug & Chug, potential for anything your advisor will allow
cons: Keep in mind this is a franchise- your experience will work based upon your advisor.

headline: A good place to work.
pros:
Great benefits
Nice co-workers
Flexible work schedule
Training tools are provided
Creation of an Employee Engagement Team, which handles employees' concerns and addresses issues
cons:
Lack of Career Development
Too much politics
People are not really promoted according to what they know, but according to who they know.

headline: A good place to work.
pros:
Great benefits
Nice co-workers
Flexible work schedule
Training tools are provided
Creation of an Employee Engagement Team, which handles employees' concerns and addresses issues
cons:
Lack of Career Development
Too much politics
People are not really promoted according to what they know, but according to who they know.

headline: it's been good so far
pros: it's been good so far
cons: Nothing specific only thing is work timing

headline: Brokerage Service Expert - Minneapolis, MN
pros: Wide diversity, Client focused business that has maintained a strong community presence despite the recent economic turmoil. Strong executive leadership that builds confidence in corporate ability to navigate changing environments.
cons: Difficult to advance as many positions within corporation leave one "pigeon-holed." Salary increases generally do not keep up with the increases in COL, and health benefit cost increases.

headline: Good company to start your career
pros: Work environment, annual increments and work life balance.
cons: salary structure is too much deffered and learning curve is very limited.

headline: If I knew then what I know now
pros: Great support people.  Overall the advisors and staff work well together
cons: As a P1 advisor your payouts are limbo stick low.  It is hard to make money on fee-based discretionary business.  Try finding a partner...good luck.  They have to go through AMP's recruiting process, and this takes alot of time.  AMP is having trouble recruiting P1 experienced advisors

headline: Life of an Associate Advisor
pros: Each practice is different, keep in mind that on the “P2” platform our franchise owners simply “lease” the Ameriprise name, technology, compliance and back office support (see cons) which means each office is run independent of the others.  My experiences have been positive:  fair compensation, reasonable life/work balance of time and stability.
cons: Interactions with the corporate office are at times frustrating and others downright aggravating.  The reliability and consistency of technology is lacking compared to peers I know at other firms.  The company has backed off of their product-centric push (i.e., sell more annuities and insurance), however that remains a looming focus.  Luckily the P2 platform allows practitioners the ability to  “take it or leave it” with respect to the wishes of the Mothership.  Biggest complaint is with frontline advisor services and a sever lack of knowledgeable assistance.  Follow through isn't the best and the standard answer is "no" until you move up the chain of command; turn-over seems high in these positions.

headline: It's a good old boys club
pros: Lots of PTO but that's really it
cons: Low base, no cost of living increases, cookie cutter philosophy - you're screwed if you do anything outside the box.

headline: Not much room for advancement
pros: Flexible hours, nice work environment, casual dress code.
cons: Slightly sexist -- for the most part, the men are the advisors, the women are the office support.  This is not the job for you if you're a woman and want to climb a ladder to a better position, or if you have a problem with fetching coffee for clients.

headline: Strong company
pros: They offer good benefits and pay, including a liberal time off policy.  You really understand how the work you do ties into the corporate objectives and goals so you feel like you are a part of something bigger than yourself.  I like the atmosphere.  In the group I am in, it is relaxed and fun, but we deliver high quality work.
cons: If you are interested in moving up within the company you have to know which leaders to hitch your wagon to because that can mean the difference between staying in the same role and not advancing for 4 years or moving up 3 levels in 2 years.

headline: Growth company with career opportunities
pros: Competitive pay, opportunity for advancement, high energy, commitment to community
cons: High expectations and workload, reorgs and layoffs not uncommon, most executive leadership located outside of Minnesota headquarters location

headline: Age Discrimination happens every day
pros: Benefits were good and community involvement was supported.
cons: Age discrimination is occurring every day and when several of us notified HR, we were all forced out of the company. They get rid of higher paid older employes and hire younger cheaper workers all the time. Poor training and lack of growth potential. They ship jobs oversees, even some accounting occurs outside the country.

headline: AAC- "Iceberg Dead Ahead!"
pros: Some decent guys to work with. mediocrity is encouraged if you like that.
cons: Where to start... This is a bad, bad, place. I have never seen management as toxic as this place. Management recruited budding advisors nationwide to join the AAC in Minneapolis, only to find out that a week into the role, they had reorganized and cut pay over 50% without any prior notice from Ameriprise. The people running this place pride themselves on "managing out" solid employees as anyone who questions this foolish plan to destroy independent relationships with clients is deemed "not on board". Next, the employees who are left have turned to substance abuse during work hours as a means of self-medicating against this awful place. Management is a bunch of failed previous advisors who are all in their 20s and there is little to no respect given to them as they seem to use their title as a dating service and routinely are seen absolutely trashed at bars on the weekends by fellow employees. The AAC management pressures advisors to sell unsuitable products to clients on every call and only pushes their Prop. products= extreme conflict of interest. Hard work is not rewarded at all and there in ZERO training in this role. The "training department" feels that rounding up a room of new hires and talking sports for an hour has effectively trained these new employees on how to sell investments?

headline: Fantastic company!
pros: Great pay, fantastic environment and general office demeanor.
cons: Financial jargon was difficult to learn at first -- stepping into an office manager role cold was quite a challenge. As soon as I got used to that, it was smooth sailing.

headline: It is a challenging place to work
pros: The insurance benefits are great and compensation is good
cons: The is a great deal of micro-management

headline: Review
pros: Work life balance and company year end bonuses are nice
cons: Commuting without real assistance can be a financial burden

headline: The independent side of Ameriprise (P2)
pros:
On the P2 platform, you can literally carve out your own piece of the pie.  For example, if a client with $1,000,000 walks in the door and agree to invest those assets at 1%, you've just given yourself an $8,000- $9,000 raise per year.  The benefit to being an entrepreneur is also the challenge; if you're not sure what I mean, this may not be the best place to start out as a Financial Advisor.  

There are a number of Team Practices on the independent platform that hire paraplanners, assistants, associate advisors... just remember, each one of these practices is it's own entity; it's own franchise.
cons: Technology was terrible, it's gotten better in the last five years but is still spotty.  In another life, the firm had some compliance hiccups.  As a result, there are some over zealous compliance policies in place (probably a good thing).

headline: Anyone over 45 can forget it
pros: Pay, time off policies, competitive benefits
cons:
Pidgeon hole people early in their careers
Political, who kisses up to who
Definite bias against anyone over 40
Say they value experience but ignore and

headline: Financial advisor
pros: Independence flexibility helping others value based people interaction
cons: Tough to get established in a practice and initial learning curve is steep

headline: Strong company still with more potential
pros: Company very stable. Conservative nature in financial services is a strong differentiator to the competition. Incentives can be very lucrative.
cons: Organizational structure is complex. Authority and decision making is closely held at the top. Collaboration could be better to yield improved results. Legacy ways things are done get in the way of progress.

headline: An exhausting place to work
pros: There are some very talented people working there. Compensation is fair. Downtown Mpls is a great place to work. Sailed through the recession financially, but at the expense of work/life balance of employees. Flexible schedules, good benefits.
cons: Never enough investment in technology. Systems have certainly improved over the past years, but phased roll-outs of incomplete systems is trying on customers and employees. So many dollars are spent to save pennies. Expect 40 hour weeks to actually be 60. Directors and Sr. Directors who are expected to be People leaders rarely lead. Many VPs rarely leave their offices and don't even acknowledge their own employees in the halls or elevator. Meetings, meetings, meetings just to have meetings.

headline: An exhausting place to work
pros: There are some very talented people working there. Compensation is fair. Downtown Mpls is a great place to work. Sailed through the recession financially, but at the expense of work/life balance of employees. Flexible schedules, good benefits.
cons: Never enough investment in technology. Systems have certainly improved over the past years, but phased roll-outs of incomplete systems is trying on customers and employees. So many dollars are spent to save pennies. Expect 40 hour weeks to actually be 60. Directors and Sr. Directors who are expected to be People leaders rarely lead. Many VPs rarely leave their offices and don't even acknowledge their own employees in the halls or elevator. Meetings, meetings, meetings just to have meetings.

headline: Good Company, beware from the peers
pros: Good Infra., Good Facilities, Employe friendly, Nice pay master
cons: Beware from your peers, your life here could in hands of your supervisor

headline: Tiresome
pros: The idea of the position is great. Helping advisors in turn helping clients invest and have more understanding and control over their own money and future.
cons:
-Political BS
-Passive Aggressive Behavior
-Blame game towards individuals, instead of taking things as a team

headline: Regional Sales Director role
pros:
Ability to make a difference in productivity of financial advisors.
Fairly independent.
Challenging
cons:
Unreasonable number of "quasi" managers to whom reporting is required
Role may not be embraced or understood by some members upper management
Ridiculous number of conference calls
Highly dependent on internal partner which can be good or bad
Unreasonable compensation for the amount of work required
Culture that is highly regimented 
Culture is one that breeds leaders with self-serving interests

headline: Overall a very energetic office environment
pros: a true professional office with lovely surroundings
cons: very specific on a foreign language background

headline: Smart capable people, but don't turn your back. There is a culture of "survival of the most selfish".
pros: fast pace environment that allows eager people to be involved
cons: bad culture. people move in and out of favor easily based upon insecurities of management

headline: It was a job...
pros: A lot of fun people, on-site gym
cons: Very sales oriented, little training

headline: Large gap between staff and Sr. Leadership
pros: Very friendly and easy to work with staff. Middle Management works hard. Good work life balance.
cons: Ameriprise projects are typically defined by Solutions architects. Unfortunately, the architects set the direction in the beginning and step away. Sr. Leadership plans and budgets on this information but there are no toll gates for checks along the way. Projects get blown out without any support from management for staff and budget.

headline: Great leadership, care about clients
pros: Great advisors.  Experienced and professional
cons: Executive leadership spends too much time fighting with each other

headline: AMP
pros: the salary is pretty good
cons: The job is pretty Boring

headline: Best company I've had the privilege of paying to work for
pros: Extensive product, marketing and technical support. Freedom to choose almost any mutual fund family to invest in. Unlimited growth potential for own practice.
cons: High expense ratio for new producers - Associate Financial Advisors - relative to income.  Monthly corporate expenses (technology,  E&O, Compliance oversight) can top $600, excluding rent and ticket charges, unless picked up by your boss.

headline: Great opportunity with solid company
pros: Great people, good company.  Excellent software tools and home/back office support.
cons: Long hours - tough job.

headline: Analyst
pros: stability, great team, steady, ok work life balance
cons: No maternity leave, have to use all vacation days, and sick days are pathetic, just 4 in a year. can pay higher, curbing flex schedules like work from home, pay per performance reviews are pathetic, performance reviews can be more streamlined and open for discussion. no upward growth, pretty stagnant, technology not upto par/.

headline: was good until it wasn't
pros: good compensation and benefits, systems easy to use, company marketing strategy generally speaking is well thought out.
cons: if you're not an advisor your value to the company is not well recognized regardless of your contributions and you are considered expendable.  Performance reviews done by supervisor who is in office once a month and without conversing with advisors who I supported.  I felt more like I was an object to be used without regard to my contribution to the organization and branch in particular.  After being unfairly harassed several times by a branch manager relatively new to the organization I was terminated for venting to a fellow employee what my opinion was of him and the advisors I supported, who were extremely satisfied with my work, had no input to the decision.  Politics seem to be alive and well.

headline: Great place to work
pros: People treat each others with respect
cons: Can't think of anything negative

headline: Fantastic company to work for!
pros: Work/life balance is great, hard work recognized and rewarded, great group of people, excellent training, flexible to work for and great benefits!
cons: Sometimes required to stay in a position for certain period of time before allowing advancement to new position even if you are qualified for the new position.

headline: Phone que TERRaBLE
author_position: Senior Cusultand, Coach On Phone Queue
pros: Location,  lunch optionsHours,  bonus,Benifets
cons: bad mgmt, in fighting between coworkers

headline: Like any big corporation - it has its ups and downs
pros: My career 15+ years ago started out great - there was great team morale and loved coming to work. Always opportunities to provide your input on improvements/innovative ideas that could be pursued.  Even through hard financial times they maintained great benefits, PTO, etc. Flexibility in some positions to be able to work alternative arrangements - occasional work from home day, 4-10 hrs days, etc.
cons: More and more overworked as layoffs happened over the last 5 years - at least in the Service Delivery organization. This led to a general feeling of heaviness hanging over that part of the organization over the last few years -  that your job could be the next one eliminated...

headline: A very toxic work environment
pros: The salary and benefits are excellent
cons: The job description may not identify series 7 as a qualification requirement, but in most positions it will become a mandatory expectation to move ahead in this company. The culture here is passive aggressive, a survival skill to get ahead or retain your current position.

headline: AAC Advisor Experience, Now CRM
pros: There has been some very good training at times, and base salary.
cons: To be clear, this is a career stop, not a career. Anyone seeking to build a career at Ameriprise should seriously consider all their options. What to expect: *Yearly reduction in pay *Constant change in terms of employment *Dishonest employment practices *Incompetent leadership Management directs client relationship manager recommendations, every client will experience a hi pressure sales call. Clients who engage in planning, will all receive managements predetermined recommendations: *Save/Retire/Accumulate plan *Disability Income Insurance *Annuity *A-share Loaded mutual funds *REITS Except by coincidence, all clients who engage with an AAC relationship will be worse off in the end. *STOP* *OMG never ever by a non-traded REIT *Never ever pay for mutual fund A-shares, or a LOAD, EVER! *You do not need DI if your employer provides it, most cases your private DI will reduce your work benefit resulting in no gain. Don't waste your money! *You don't need an annuity with living benefits, they are criminally expensive, and only benefit the sales organization, in many cases only 100k of your annuity is insured! *START* Real Financial Advisors Recommend *Buy Term, and invest in SPS *Only self insured professionals need Disability Insurance The AAC used to be a sales driven segment of Ameriprise. The AAC is now a socially run frat-house where relationships, drinking, and drugs are common culture. If you are looking for a quick stop in your career seeking to get your financial licenses, training, and a designation. The Ameriprise AAC is an okay, but VERY risky option.

headline: Great opportunity in growing field, but has drawbacks
pros: Flexibility in how to run your business is a huge positive. In addition, the support from the Corporate office is pretty good and getting better. Finally, the pay out structure is pretty good given the level of support provided.
cons: Slow to change and adopt new modes of thinking. You have an intimate working relationship with the Advisors and if you don't get along it can create a horrible work place.

headline: Good People. Poor decision making.
pros:
Brand recognition. 
Downtown location. Everyone is willing to help you. Solid culture.
cons: They say they're forward thinking but they are not. Their so called leads are just customers they don't have a real relationship with. You'll make hundreds of calls hoping to set 1-2 appointments. They know it is a poor way to produce results but it was the only way to produce results unless your natural market can do it for you. High turnover unless your lucky.

headline: Company is in a good industry, but good executive leadership is sorely lacking.
pros:
It's great to work in an industry that helps people.
My job is a good fit for my talents.
I enjoy working with the people I interface with on a daily basis.
cons:
Integrity should be removed as a company guiding principal, since so few leaders demonstrate it.
Too many undeserved promotions, company is very top heavy.

headline: Paraplanner
pros: I love my co-workers. You tend to band together to get the job done.
cons: Advisors are in complete control of their office. They can say and do anything they want with no ramifications from Ameriprise because they are a Franchise owner.

headline: Good opportunity for experienced Advisor with existing book of business
pros: No huge focus on proprietary products. Objective needs analysis and ability to offer decent wealth management products. Good company for franchise advisors.
cons: Too much corporate mandating and changing to fix things that aren't broken. Lower than average payout and comp grid way too complex and constantly changing. Hard to maintain focus on client relationships. Too much paper and not enough streamlined technology.

headline: It has been a wild ride
pros: Great learning opportunities to meet people and learn product.  The training is mostly good in the beginning but it does drop off significantly over time.
cons: Strategic direction of my division changed radically and quickly a number of times.  Overall the company seems clear, but my division appears to be all over the place.

headline: Great opportunities to do true textbook corporate finance
pros: Good management within the finance organization, high investment in finance
cons: Poor organizational and process leadership

headline: Great place to learn the financial planning and investment industry.
pros:
Access to training and technology is second to none.
The advisor I worked for was a terrific mentor.
cons:
Most offices are independent franchises so the paraplanner experience will vary depending on the advisor that hires you.
The home office call center can be frustrating to work with and is often unhelpful.
Compliance is overbearing and literally monitors everything you type.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good opportunities for career growth
cons: Need more cross org collaboration

headline: Excellent organization to work for
pros: Good work environment, Competitive compensation, High annual bonuses, Work-life balance, Supportive management and clients
cons: negligible when compared to pros

headline: Varied experience
pros: Good people who are very bright
cons: Change is rapid and not thought out well.Employees are simply numbers and their tenure is not a concern. Only their current usefullness

headline: Good Company
pros: Employee Friendly, Good environment, good paymaster
cons: Poor Management, lack of flexibility.

headline: Working as paraplanner for F PLanner
pros: Flexibility, your work speaks for itself, lack of office politics, oppty to advance, oppty to work and interact with business owner, president
cons: You need to do your research on pay for when you are hired, for performance review and for promotion  -- at times.  Sometimes you have to remind mgmt on your contributions.  But you should do that anyway.   You need to be able to communicate on problems with delays, etc. ---- you need to be a confident person.

headline: good, client focused
pros: marketing is great, access to information is good.  Even though the company is public, it has a small company feel and treats the FAs well.
cons: pay for FAs cut over the past 2 years.  Not as bad as Wires, but headed in that direction.  I hope they stop while they are ahead.

headline: A company on the move
pros: Mid western Culture that values work life balance
cons: No movement between groups, very little movement between groups

headline: One foot in the unemployment line, one foot on a banana peel
pros: Good people, high energy firm.  They do good work that benefits America.
cons: Leadership treats the employees, advisors, and clients as resources to be managed to the benefit of the shareholder, much the same way that your would treat office furniture.  They play too fast and too loose with people's careers, laying them off with little forethought and little reason.

headline: Very good
pros: Provided good financial access and help.
cons: Did not assist interns well

headline: Great for the first four years and the last three did not go as well as planned.
pros: Great community care and benefits.
cons: Employees do not advance without networking constantly. Networking is another name for wasted work time.

headline: Not for MeFOR
pros: I worked in an inviting environment with some excellent people. I was included in the group from day one.
cons: Too many conversations with compliance. I support and appreciate their assistance, but much of the stuff was silly. A lot of "we didn't receive that" from corporate support. Rework.

headline: It was not a fulfilling experience.
pros: The Home and Regional Office support was great, and the new integrated platform was a much-needed improvement.
cons: The Franchise Advisor arrangement and lack of corporate advertising was a great disadvantage.

headline: It was not a fulfilling experience.
pros: The Home and Regional Office support was great, and the new integrated platform was a much-needed improvement.
cons: The Franchise Advisor arrangement and lack of corporate advertising was a great disadvantage.

headline: Great company to work for.  Lots of room for advancement.
pros: Ameriprise has a amazing ability to work with different groups of employees.  Their employee networks are top notch.  The benefits are above average.
cons: One of the downsides for working for a large corporation such as Ameriprise is that an employee can be more of a number than a person.

headline: well run company compared to competition
pros: hard work pays off for those that want it. ameriprise is a very stable company and will be around for a long time
cons: leaders can be flaky. development can be hard to come by. don't drink too much of the kool aid

headline: Ideal Working Conditions
pros: Jeffrey S. London, under whom I work at Ameriprise, is politie, patient, flexible, and considerate to a fault. He has assembled a team, with whom I work, that are identical to him in every way. Respect, success, patience, warmth, and kindness and flexibility are the operative words here. I could not have a better Part-Time situation.
cons: There are none I can think of.

headline: Ameriprise needs to manage their leaders
pros: Ameriprise has good benefits and great paid time off available to employees.   Depending on the area of the company you work in, you may also have the option of flexible work hours or working from home.  The majority of my leaders have been excellent.
cons: Long term employees seemed to be the first to go with layoffs. There is currently a director in  my department that continues to be in a leadership role despite a large number of complaints against the person.  The impact this person is having on  poor morale and productivity is very significant.  Many good employees have left the company because of this director.  I don't understand why the company keeps this person in a leadership position.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Wonderful co-workers and room for advancement.
cons: Senior leadership can sometimes be detached from the situations their staff encounter

headline: I worked for a franchise of Ameriprise, not the actual company, and it was the worst experience in my career.
pros: Ameriprise Financial is a good company to work for, assuming you work for the actual company. They offer career growth opportunities, good benefits, 401(k) and tuition reimbursement.
cons: When I was being interviewed by the advisor, now franchise owner, he never told me they were transitioning to a franchise. He did say they were moving to a new office but I thought he meant the entire branch. Once I started working for Ameriprise I realized fast that he was very inconstant. He had offered me more money when I was hired and when I brought it up he acted like he had no recollection of the conversation. I was foolish enough not to get it in writing. The advisors are rude to all support staff constantly talking down to them. The franchise owner views advisors as revenue and support staff as an expense.

headline: little brand recognition
pros: too few as no longer have access to tax clients
cons: no one knows that this is an investment advisory firm

headline: It was a wonderful learning experience and a challenge which I love
pros: Great dedicated people, good concepts, great benefits and opportunities
cons: The recruiting spreads too wide a net for the type of position not enough really qualified people and the training for new Advisers is lacking. They are thrown to their own devices way too soon and it's all about getting the clients but not what to do once you have one.  With the proper training more would stay instead of giving up!

headline: Very rewarding, learned a ton and helped people along the way
pros: I work with a great advisor who has mentored me tremendously
cons: Acrss the financial services industry, fees keep increasing which isn't great for clients. The government has continued to make it harder to do well in this business with their increased regualtory requirements. This is all due to the client abuse from unethical advisors like Madoff, this has now made it difficult for the good advisors to conduct business as usual.

headline: Great people
pros: The people are great to work with. Awesome amount of PTO.
cons: There is little effort to push employees to take continuing ed to develop skills. Pay is not at current market level for the area.

headline: It is a good organization to stay in
pros: Good environment to work with satisfying opportunities  and a good work life balance.
cons: Can improvise on some of its policies on granular level to make a better place to work.

headline: Nice place to work overall would recommend. t
pros: Have all the tools to work with
cons: Pretty tight compliance, no discretion allowed unless cfa.

headline: Good place to gain experience and further your career
pros:
Good career opportunities
Compensation & Benefits
Culture - employee clubs, health club
cons:
Work/life balance in technology area can be hard to maintain.  While the company promotes balance, you are expected to maintain a heavy workload and be available when needed.

Not enough technical training offered to employees creating the need to hire outside of the company

headline: am increasing sense of desperation
pros: jobs on the service queues are getting easier - there's much more focus on following norms and adherence to policy than on doing all you can to make it happen .
cons: There's a sense of blood in the water. . it's finally occuring to senior management that instead of throwing so many resources at recovery from poor service, it may be a little more cost effective to focus on doing it right the first time.   those efforts are succeeding, which means that multiple layers of managers and vp's devoted to indivualized conduits for complaints are trying to justify their existence and finding it rather tough going.  it seems to take more and more effort for them to keep their smiles pasted on  and keep doing their happy dance to keep enough rats on the ship until they finally pull the plug.  i see more layoffs and a lot of scrambling in the near future

headline: Started out well but deteriorated quickly when we realized management is prepping the jobs to go off-shore.
pros: Not a lot of great things to mention.  Some people there are great, but the atmosphere went sour when hundreds of jobs went to India.
cons: Leadership is non-existent.  Management is constantly changing what they wanted and passed blame for their performance down the chain daily.

headline: They didn't know what they were doing
pros: The center was pretty new when I arrived, but they had no idea what was going on. They helped you get license and paid for your training which is pretty rare in the industry.
cons:
A lot of training on nothing.
They only care about selling financial plans
Management likes to baby you.
Things have changed a lot since they brought in the consultants and restructured

headline: A fine place to settle in
pros:
Atmosphere
Progressive Leadership
Easy to move both around and up within company
Wages
Benefits
Free or Discounted financial services
cons:
Can still be a typical corporate environment
Can be tough to get your foot in the door

headline: Great place to start career.
pros: Great benefits and employee clubs. Extremely philanthropic company. Knowledgeable people.
cons: Slow decision making.  Little employee empowerment.  Older workers not as apt to change.

headline: Good company, smart people
pros: Ameriprise is a solid company with good benefits and bonuses. Excellent work life balance. On the corporate side, the whole company clears out at 5 p.m. Overall a very positive culture.
cons: It's a very conservative with a slow pace of change which can be frustrating if you work with online initiatives.

headline: great company
pros: great career if you love helping people with lifelong goals
cons: work can carry over after 5 oclock on your own time and many qualifications and tests are required if you want to move up in the business.....but it's worth it

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Great people, lots of opportunities to move within the company
cons: Lots of talented people to compete with!

headline: Strong Leadership
pros: I find the top leadership in the company to be very efficient and focused on growing.  The company provides necessary tools to complete the job at hand.
cons: Heavy fees for start up advisors and marketing tools can be quite expensive when they don't necessarily have to be.

headline: At times, excellent, but at others disappointing and frustrating.
pros: PTO is very competitive with the option to buy an additional week. Often the people you work with are wonderful and become close friends. There are some "good apple" directors and VPs, but most lose their soul after a few years.
cons:
There are two standards for displacement. If someone is troublesome, difficult to work with, or even has complaints against them to HR, their job is safe as Ameriprise seems to be afraid of lawsuits of any kind. However, when senior leadership wants to cut costs, which seems to happen on an annual basis in November, loyal and hard-working employees are laid off in droves, primarily in the service organization. Layoffs can happen anywhere in the enterprise, except the finance department.

There are two distinct cultures: service and everyone else. "Everyone else" looks down on service with disdain even though it's apparent that the service organization works harder than most of the rest of the company by the amount of Target shopping bags entering the headquarters building during the lunch hour. Only a select few service workers can leave the service building because of restrictive lunch hours. This culture also permeates product implementations and communications with the public and advisor group where service is often forgotten or blatantly ignored in project and communication planning.

headline: Lies, Lies and more Lies
pros: Paid training (albeit by trainers who were failures as advisors), paid licenses, before the change coming if you were a hard worker and knew how to dial you could be successful, multicultural, nice co-workers, used to have overtime, weak would fail, good sales environment, great location downtown, females are given every opportunity to be successful.
cons: Managers are failed advisors (they tried to hire managers from outside the company,because there is no respect for managers who couldn't produce, and this failed) most if not all current managers are weak, managers were given raises while top advisors are being transitioned over to service roles, minimal respect for hard working employees, top 20% of advisors are getting a pay cut while bottom 80% are happy with a higher base, you're not a true advisor you're a service monkey, leads are not handed out fairly, if you kiss ass you are given better opportunities then those who posses higher skill levels.

headline: Decent place to work, however salary not withing industry standards
pros: Great benefits, great people, growing business
cons: Low salary, some areas have very poor training

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Nice building/facility, great guys to work with.
cons: 4 months after I started they changed the role/compensation model on us.

headline: Great company to work for and benefits not bad
pros: A very relaxed work environment.
cons: Lacks good professional development programs.

headline: The worst job ever stay away
pros: My co workers were great
cons:
The benefits are a joke
The management and the advisors treat you like dirt
Pay was really bad
Advisor cut in programme was optional so most didn't bother

headline: Toxic Marketing Culture
pros: Benefits, downtown Minneapolis location, cafeteria, opportunity to meet a lot of good people, very secure environment, domestic partner benefits.
cons: A fear-based culture in Marketing made working there a nightmare. Managers and directors have no decision-making ability. Everything is micro-managed to an unimaginable degree by VPs and executive management. Nearly every, single piece created by Marketing needs to be reviewed by the CMO. Things that typically take days to complete in other organizations can take month upon painful month at AMP. "Yes" people are revered and promoted into "leadership" roles they are not qualified to hold. CYA behaviors are abundant because of bad management. If you like to think outside the box and you value being empowered in your job -- run like the wind. If you don't mind being massively micro-managed, it could work for you.

headline: Great place to start......but that's about it.
pros: Sponsor for licensing and fun people to work with. It's also a great place to network. There is also restructure happening that may mold well to some people.
cons: Unrealistic expectation to sell products with a high fees. If you are looking for a place to do actively managed portfolios this is not the place for you.

headline: Great place to start a new career
pros: Great benefits, community participation and training support. Lots of clients to talk to on the phone.
cons: You must be prepared to study hard for licenses. You will have to work long hours to meet the goals set for you

headline: Insurance company, proprietary products and micro management
pros: high pay for upper middle management
cons:
micro management, micro management, micro management
middle to upper management extremely overpaid, arrogant and disingenuous 
everything outcome leads to an insurance product
cutting payouts every year for the past 2 and likely will continue for another 2 or more
kids with no street cred trying to lead veterans
like a cult

headline: Great company to grow and develop at.
pros: The company has a strong team of executives that have done a great job leading the company through the economic ups and downs over the last six years.
cons: Leaders are not empowered take necessary steps to retain talented people.

headline: If you wanna do sales while knowing nothing about your industry. Work here. No industry training.
pros: If you have industry experience and a book of clients before working here, then it could be worth it.
cons: No training. Just how to sell a product you don't understand.

headline: Good place to start a career with little-to-no experience
pros: Slow-paced (if you like it), location is downtown, good place to start a career with little-to-no experience.  The AAC advisor training is thorough and offers ongoing education.
cons: The workplace is fierce.  Passive aggressive managers set the tone for everyone else.  Employees (not advisors) are very disengaged from their jobs.  Fear and intimidation is used extensively to get the job done.  Tenure is everything at AMP--unless you're part of the ELT.  There is not much career opportunity for growth within departments (mainly because there are too many departments to begin with).  Overlapping work is very common and creates employee frustration when too many business partners are involved with the same tasks/projects.  Innovation and efficiency (within the CSC) is viewed with open contempt to destroy tenured peoples' positions and processes that have worked since they were hired (for many that is decades).  Information is closely held within teams for fear that sharing it will lead to their demise.  Lastly, leadership confidence has gone down considerably which affects everything.

headline: Great If you are on the backend of your career
pros: Steady Paycheck, Friendly Work Environment
cons: No room for professional growth or promotion/ Not much salary growth

headline: Liked my job
pros: Like my work, liked my co-workers, liked my boss, liked the company, liked my salary, liked my benefits
cons: No major draw back to job.  Enjoyed my time while at the company.  No additional comments.

headline: Good experience, very professional company
pros: Friendly upbeat atmosphere, most people in the company are eager to help you find your way
cons: Not for everyone, becomes extremely competitive and fast paced

headline: Ameriprise is searching for a way to grow but misses the mark consistantly
pros: Best company in the industry to get your training at least it used to be. I learned everything I need to succeed.
cons: Management was ineffectual, and unaware of how to run a sales room. Management didn't reward success.  It's a culture of mediocrity.

headline: Ameriprise is searching for a way to grow but misses the mark consistantly
pros: Best company in the industry to get your training at least it used to be. I learned everything I need to succeed.
cons: Management was ineffectual, and unaware of how to run a sales room. Management didn't reward success.  It's a culture of mediocrity.

headline: Franchise Employee
pros: Great place to work. Up-to-date on technology and systems. Great support from back office.
cons: No benefits / support for franchise employees.

headline: Depending on your leader, can be a great place or the worst place to work.
pros: Big company, decent benefits, great people to work with most of the time.
cons: Recent benefit cuts, poor culture in some departments, poor leaders get promoted. There is a culture of micromanagement and some areas are really bad to the point where senior level employees are not able to make any decisions without checking in. This results in low morale among employees. Some areas also treat women worse than their male peers.

headline: Intern
pros: Working with my family on investment related topics
cons: sometimes not much to do because I am not certified

headline: Happy to NOT be there
pros: Salary ranges are competitive and the downtown Minneapolis location, while not in the core of downtown, is attractive for many.
cons: Wow. Where to start. The vulture is one of micro-management, passive aggressive leadership and lack of decision-making, empowement or trust. They may talk a good game but the experience of employees at all levels is demoralizing. Employees are not encouaged to take risks, be creative or collaborate. Managers -- they call them leaders -- are selected and promoted based on results only , not people skils, mentoring, coaching or team-building. Fear-based management is the norm.

headline: Financial Planning Career
pros: Great place to begin a career in financial planning because of the base salary.
cons: Captured agent which limits your ability to meet the needs of a diverse client base

headline: Met some really great people.
pros: A financially conservative company that strives to find new ways to improve the customer experience.  The comp is good, nice time off policies, and gym.
cons: Cyclical model of hiring and layoffs. Just like clock work every three to five years there is an aggressive push to lower costs and it is done through layoffs.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
* Lots of employee networks and interest clubs
* Leaders are very supportive in helping you find the right long-term role. They encourage you to "shop around" at other departments in the company. 
* Lots of opportunities for advancement and self development
cons: * Not always sure where salary/compensation is compared to other companies. Some departments will share research showing compensation is at/above average. Other departments leave employees in dark.

headline: Your experience at Ameriprise depends on your leader
pros: Company truly committed to its customers
cons: Depending on the area within the company and your leader, there can be expectations that are impossible to meet.

headline: Good company to Join
pros:
Good Salary,Work Life balance,Management  & HR Policies are very good.
Lucrative Bonus.
cons:
Not good technical work. You have to get work from business.
Mostly Vendors are doing the work rather than permanent employee.

headline: Supportive
pros: Professional development and career advancement opportunities are there.  The company will invest in the aforementioned to increase their pool of talent.  I've been able to further my education and develop as a professional with support from Ameriprise.
cons: The technology lags behind the industry.  Our knowledge software is weak but it is improving and you can forget about our website.  It's not possible to do even the most basic transaction: move money internally.

headline: Re-structuring will help retention rate of employees
pros: get a book of clients, full service and support
cons: no room for growth, bad structure, some micromanagement, conflict of interest placed on advisors by management between doing what's best for the client and proprietary products.

headline: Not the best for administrative assistants.
pros:
Great coworkers
Good pay, benefits, bonus
cons: Majority of administrative assistant role is scheduling, rescheduling, cancelling and making arrangements for a never-ending stream of meetings.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Plenty of opportunities in this growing company
cons: Salary is lower than competitors

headline: Great Starting off point, but not a lifetime career
pros: People, Experience, Community, Job Opportunies, Ability to move between departments
cons: Salary, Politics, Culture, Performance Review Process,

headline: Paraplanner
pros: The converson to the Thomson trading platform was a wise decision since it is an industry standard.
cons:
Home office support is inconsistant/outsourced with language barriers. Most of the departments do not accept phone calls and department e-mails are often ignored. 
The company only focuses on its franchise owners and does not consider office "staff" as Ameriprise Employees.
Regardless of licensing, the staff does not have access to the reports it needs to manage business.  
The staff cannot sign forms in lieu of the advisor making it impossible to submit client requests when the advisor is out of the office.

headline: Not A true financial planning firm
pros: Still thinking..... Oh, they have nice offices to try to impress potential clients.
cons: Where do I start... If you are independent and you are considering working with them, don't. You lose your rights to your clients. They will try to keep them if you leave and threaten to sue you if you try to bring your clients with you. When I starting into the Ameriprise culture, I learned all the wrong things to do. Both my so called managers were fired for the inappropriate investment recommendations to my clients. All their recommendations include RAVA Annuity, VUL,  A shares mutual funds and disability.  Management pressures you to sell just these products.

headline: Great company for development
pros:
-Pretty good work/life balance.
-Competitive pay.
-Co-Workers are fantastic.
-Lot of chances to move up within the company.
cons:
-Sometimes role gets tedius.
-Working with other areas of the company is sometimes difficult.
-Rarely, but has happened, hard work and talent is not always rewarded.

headline: Good company
pros: lots of good benefits and opportunities for advancement in a variety of fields.  There's a lot of online training available .  If you're identified as someone your manager wants to develop, the sky's the limit.  There are no qualms about giving selected people more opportunities to advance.
cons: political, lots of competition and layoffs are a current threat.  There's much more pressure lately and it shows in the tension of managers and the atmosphere is much more strained.  Much more focus on the numbers and bottom line than there is on the harder to measure qualities like client satisfaction.   Advisors seem unhappier - the veterans are paying more and getting less and the newly recruited advisors are finding things aren't exactly as they were told.

headline: Great company to work for.
pros: Lots of opportunities for growth, fast paced, successful company with a bright future. Great learning ground for anyone looking to get into the financial industry.
cons: When a company gets this big, it means committees and meetings to discuss the committees. That can be a drag at times.

headline: Great company to work for.
pros: Lots of opportunities for growth, fast paced, successful company with a bright future. Great learning ground for anyone looking to get into the financial industry.
cons: When a company gets this big, it means committees and meetings to discuss the committees. That can be a drag at times.

headline: Very professional team, but small pay
pros: Well known Company, good to have in your resume
cons: Very Small Salary, slow promotion

headline: Great Company to Work For
pros: Great benefits, great leaders and great co-workers
cons: Salary could be more for a registered representative who holds a Series 7 and Seriess 66 licenses as opposed to those who don't hold the license.

headline: Very bureaucratic company with no happy culture inside work place
pros:
The location and the amenities are good.
Holds a great cafe and gym inside the building.
Compensation is good compared to other locations.
Have higher value in yourself if you are in the company for long time.
cons:
Cannot show passion at workplace, always leaders dictate any direction.
Senior leaders aren't aware of latest greatest industrial standards which makes junior co-works inhibit any new approach.
No personal value in the company.
Process are old school and never being revisited to help work culture flourish.

headline: Desparately seeking to leave
pros: It is located in downtown Minneapolis.
cons: You are constanly micromanaged and bombarded with unreasonable expectations

headline: Political playground has made the company lose focus on effectiveness.
pros: Competitive pay and benefits. The benefits seem to be above average for Minneapolis, despite gradually eroding year over year. Those who have been with the company for many years have excellent pay and unmatched vacation allotments.
cons:
Extremely politically charged environment. There are political players in many leadership roles delighting themselves in their personal quests for domination. This poisonous layer of upper-middle management tends to sour the people perspective of the whole organization.

Lack of investment in innovation. Talent has been consistently leaving the company in critical technology spaces.

headline: Good company
pros: They try to keep ahead of industry trends.  Good home office support.
cons: A lot of fees for advisors

headline: Lots of opportunity if you're in Minneapolis
pros: Very supportive or work life balance, hard to get mentorship on lower levels
cons: Most of the opportunities are in Minneapolis

headline: Easiest back office to work with.
pros: Strong company and resources are abundant.
cons: Technology is behind others in its field. Constant website issues that lock clients out of their own online access.

headline: Worst company for which I've ever worked
pros:
The company puts clients and their needs first, and they take fiduciary responsibilities very seriously.
Costs of services are reasonable by industry standards.
Great personal satisfaction in helping clients to achieve their goals.
Home Office representatives are very knowledgeable, helpful, and resourceful.
cons:
Senior management has a very antagonistic and exploitive attitude towards field staff. 
Employees working in franchised advisor practices are excluded from all company benefits—neither health insurance nor disability coverage, and not even access to the company’s retirement plan nor ESPP.
User-hostile technology and unannounced changes to processes and procedures are extremely frustrating and set you up for constant failure.
Raises are even less than inflation, thus guaranteeing that your purchasing power will go down regardless of job performance. Compensation in general is extraordinarily unfair, with 100% of income growth going to executives and advisors even though staff does all of the actual work.
Franchise staffs are specifically excluded from the employee satisfaction survey. Senior management doesn’t care nor want to know about your on-the-job challenges even though you’re the public face of the company.
Don’t take a job with Ameriprise unless you’re really desperate, and even then get out asap; long-term, it’s a dead-end without opportunities for advancement.

headline: Lots of Learning
pros: Emphasis on development and learning, espeically in their Financial Leadership Development Program. Paying for finanical exams and having technical classes are helfpul. They rotate you around which is great.
cons: Hard to move around in the company. There isn't much room for growth (especially at Columbia Managment in Boston). There isn't much focus on paying entry level. The focus is on the sales team. That is where there is growth.

headline: You'll be successful, if you can take the stress.
pros: Great pay, good alternative work arrangements - if you land up in the right dept, good benefits.
cons: Work is stressful at best. Yo-Yo ing of staffing and layoffs is stressful. If you can take stress and thrive, this place has a lot to offer.

headline: Know Your Worth, because Ameriprise doesn't.
pros: Headquarters has more professional environment and opportunities than the CSC - Client Service Center.
cons:
Ameriprise Financial, CSC- Client Service Center, MInneapolis, MN 

Fake, fear-based, culture.  Most team leaders and directors take an extremely disingenuous approach to team members so pervasive that it has almost completely contaminated my colleagues ( in other words, a lot of people come across phony, like they are acting the "Pro Ameriprise Brand. " )

The overall mood most people have is , "Look, this is just a job, I don't really care about any of this, but let's just do our best to pretend to be really excited about these "Dream it, Do It"  financial services we provide but can't afford to invest in ourselves. "
  
The most challenging aspect of working at Ameriprise , the #1 Con, is trying to motivate yourself to care about work that you feel your own leader/director/direct report doesn't really care about. There is simply no heart in the work. 

Maybe some of the negativity is because it's hard to relate to our very wealthy, affluent clients.   Unfortunately, what happens when you don't have  Heart, when you don't have anything Real to work with or for, when you don't have  a personal, relatable company mission and vision to love and believe in... then all that is left is " Me, Me, Me, 'Get out of my way' I will do whatever I have to do to climb this ladder , and doing good, creative, intelligent work doesn't get rewarded here so I will do whatever I have to do to appear better than my coworkers."

headline: Hard to get going
pros: I don't work very hard
cons: I don't get paid very much

headline: Excellent
pros:
Results Oriented Workplace
Flexible hours and schedule
Work at home options
Opportunities for advancement
cons: Sometimes management has lack of long term focus

headline: interesting
pros: paid training and some control over the hours worked
cons:
lack of support 
feels like a training ground 
they hire anybody off the street

headline: Good place to work and grow
pros: A diverse group of businesses; good work/life balance; growing into new markets
cons: Some downsizing recently, slow customer growth

headline: Ameriprise Advisor Center Minneapolis MN
pros: They pay for your licenses. The trainers do their best to prepare you for trying to work with clients. A stepping stone to a better firm.
cons: Too many to list. Long hours, diminished client base. Toxic management and expectation from them to churn client accounts. Most advisors don't make it past 2 years. The system almost seems designed to get people termed after 18-24 months. The job has continually gotten worse in the two years I have been there. The senior leadership does not seem to understand what is happening in a rather large department of their company.

headline: Good Company to Work For
pros: Lot's of Product to offer for Solutions to client's situations.
cons: Affluent not familiar with the name.

headline: Adviser Training AAC
pros:
Paid full time and received immediate benefits when studying for Series 7, 63, Life/health licenses. 

Great leadership who will do anything in their ability to help you.
cons:
-Cold calling bad leads who have absolutely no interest in talking to you.

-AAC Advisers are known as the "shark tank" to field advisers because they call the leads or (clients that are dumped by other advisers) in order to build a practice from.

headline: Good, solid company, not much upward mobility
pros: Strong company with excellent values and strong financials, good work environment if you are working with the right advisor, good opportunity if you're on the advisory career track
cons: very little upward mobility if you're not on the advisory track.  Depending on the situation, salaries can be very low, and often with little to offer when it comes to benefits.

headline: Great place to work. Excellent
pros: Great corporate office support staff
cons: none that I can think of

headline: I worked for the brokerage operations department as a employee stock option trader.
pros: Good ground floor opportunity for office work and the securities industry while studying in school.
cons: Very hard to advance within the company. Pretty uninspired staff. Most people are just punching a clock.

headline: I was a former HRBFA advisor and we were purchased by Ameriprise
pros: The payout is good in releation to similar production levels at wire houses
cons: Compliance is very strict.  They do not want you to trade stocks they do not cover or reccommend options.  The firm has a case number for everything, and does not comprehend that an error is a timely situation.

headline: Customer Service Pro
pros: Good co-workers,  Lots of resources to develop your career
cons: Hard place to move up.  Working in the Service Delivery it is hard to make much even if you do move up.

headline: Great place to work. Period.
pros: Great People in all areas
cons: Some stupid people, as to be expected

headline: Financial Advisor - Independent Franchisee
