pros: Work independently. Develop business in a variety of ways with focus on the type of client desired.  Equity ownership in franchise.  Full array of financial products.  Good product support at corporate level.
cons: Lots of internal changes.  Changes in payout rates.  Lack of support at the advisor/frachise level.  Once franchise is sold, not allowed to work for the company.  Good array of products, sometimes not competetive for clients.

headline: Way better than working for a bank! AAC Minneapolis, MN.
pros: Good compensation. Great coworkers. Very good manager who actually cared about his team. You can sell whatever you think is best for clients. Base salary. Leads were pretty good when I started.
cons: Work life balance is pretty bad, late nights and long hours. Technology is terrible, so bad that its not worth complaining about, you have sales to make. The leads are now terrible, these people have been called weekly for 1.5 years by someone different every week. A few unethical Advisors and Managers.

headline: From 0 to 60 in no time flat, a fantastic sales and financial advisor training program
pros: Rewarding career helping others with their financial plans. Great income potential
cons: Requires 150% to get your business off the ground. If you aren't a people person who can pull 60hr weeks, look elsewhere.

headline: Good place to start a financial services career
pros: Franchised offices get a certain level of autonomy and depending on your office you may have room for quick growth
cons: Home office support and technology lags behind some competitors

headline: HIghly structured roles that can work for some people
pros: Excellent co-workers and good benefits
cons: It is a Factory job

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Sales and marketing bootcamp - good for experience
cons: Work alongside vultures who will steal your prospects and care about nothing but meeting their own numbers, including your manager!

headline: At the Ameriprise Advisor Center, long hours in a call center environment
pros: Paid licensing and training. The office location is nice overlooking McCarren, and the cafeteria has a good mix of some decent food.
cons: Lots of overtime expected. Work weeks of 50-60 hours are typical. It's a call center environment, and churning of client assets and accounts is seemingly acceptable and one of the only ways to make anything beyond base + overtime.

headline: mixed feeling
pros: strong financials, strong marketing, good product, significant support is given to the advisors to help them grow their business
cons: a lot od back stabbing in management, don't trust anyone, a lot of people will turn on you behind your back

headline: Positive place, motivated people.
pros: Ameriprise has a flexible environment and a lot of good people; there are a lot of opportunities to move up into other positions in different departments.
cons: There is a fair amount of red tape; as with many large corporations, decisions are often made not by subject matter experts but by the highest paid person in the room.

headline: My experience at Ameriprise
pros: They have a great compensation package, including help with daycare! They care about their employees and will work to help your needs met, including flextime
cons: Some departments micro manage to an extreme

headline: Financial advisor- Las Vegas, NV advisor center
pros:
Hourly wage
commission
Decent benefits
401k is through wells fargo
Pay for all your series and insurance licensing
cons:
Glorified telemarketer.
Low commission grid rate
High turn-over
Everything needs to be done over the phone
leads are recycled over and over and over

headline: Good People, but Increasingly Stressful Culture
pros:
Decent pay and benefits
Access to a decent gym in the home office in Minneapolis
cons: Expect to get ridden and have work dumped on you the lower on the ladder you start. The culture had worsened and become more stressful (fewer perks and more responsibility for no appreciable increase in pay) over the years I worked there. Sad thing is this is likely just the trend in the economy of the set decade.

headline: A solid company, but tough to grow your business
pros: Strong company, good management.  The Ameriprise name has been improving over the last few years.
cons: It's a tough place to grow your business as an advisor.  They are in transition from the days of "lunch and learns" to the model of a more traditional wire house.

headline: stay away
pros: Get sponsored for your licensing exams
cons: Some bad apples make working there very unsavory

headline: Financial planning is the right idea for today's consumer, execution isn't always there
pros:
In concept, the financial planning model is ideal, especially in this economy.
The overall business model of a broker/dealer, asset manager and insurance company makes sense as the three elements support each other.
cons:
Not all the advisors are true financial planners, and even those that are can't always handle too much complexity.
Senior management is too disconnected from the rank in file organization.
By distancing themselves from the insurance element of the business, they're missing a great opportunity to bring balance to client portfolios through guaranteed accounts and the tax and saving benefits of whole life insurance.

headline: Working for Ameriprise
pros: Excellent benefits - Competitive salary
cons: Silo mentality - teamwork is not encouraged or valued. Leadership and leader development is absent

headline: Rewarding if you are prepared to work very hard and be exhausted at times
pros: It is a wonderful place to get licensed and see if being a financial advisor is what you want to do. Once you have a book of business you can scale back a bit. If you do not want to be an advisor, it is a good path to other positions at corporate HQ.
cons: Colleagues drop like flies-retention rate from training class after 1st year was 20%

headline: Glad to be with Ameriprise
pros: Work independently as a franchise, and still have the support of a home office behind you and your practice.
cons: No cons at this time.

headline: Ameriprise grinds people up and spits them out.
pros: They pay well. There are always interesting projects and things happening. Many of your coworkers will be fun and interesting people.
cons: They work at bare bone staffing and expect maximum output at all times. Management isoblivious to the amount of time and effort put in by many and when they are made aware, they don't care - as long as the work is done. Marketing is the WORST. You will work long hard hours until you are burnt out. I worked there for 20 years and saw it over and over, until I was burnt out.

headline: Great place to start a career
pros: While this may change from department to department. I have found the organization to be supportive of career growth and committed to retaining high performers. The minneapolis campus has a wide array of support services on site.
cons: Being a financial services firms there is layers upon layers of rules and regulations. More a reflection of the industry than the firm.

headline: Project Coordinator
pros: A few people have turned out to be solid good people, unfortunately because the culture is so bad, these positive people can not influence and impact the right kind of change.  The cafetiere is subsidized and offers healthy options.
cons: Horrible culture; shame and blame game context, majority of management does not know how to hold people accountable, excuses and hiding issues are rewarded.  If you are a high performer with integrity this is not the company to work for.  Contractors are treated terrible, if issues come up the employees will blame the contractors, the contractors have no recourse are being treated with disrespect and abusive.

headline: The worst company to work for in the industry
pros:
Flexible work times
The ping pong table
cons:
Company does regular layoffs because they aren't smart enough to staff appropriately
Pay is way below industry average
Outsiders know the company is a joke
Do not care about education.  They only care about how many years you have worked there.
Managers only hire happy hour buddies

headline: The best place to work in gurgaon Ameriprise finacial services
pros: Great experience, great working culture, excellent facilities, good promotional opportunities,great salary
cons: Long working hours, lack of discipline and over friendly relations between employes and employer that hampers productivity

headline: An assistant position at an Ameriprise franchise is a good way to get your foot in the door of financial services.
pros: Employees and advisers are friendly, honest, productive, helpful.  The adviser gives you a good sense of what being an adviser is actually all about. Once the adviser has confidence in your ability, he or she will generally allow you to take on all of the responsibilities of an adviser, aside from the ones precluded to you by law. The adviser helps you understand sales in a way that simultaneously retains clients as genuine friends.
cons: There were not many cons. Depending on the number of accounts your adviser handles and client needs, you may need to stay past the usual eight hours, but this is rare. Currently, it is difficult if not impossible to be hired as an adviser with Ameriprise.

headline: dysfunctional from day one.....
pros: they didn't charge for the air you breath at work....
cons: managements left hand never knows what the right hand is doing....

headline: It was the most strange, dysfunctional and painful employer of my career.
pros: They pay decently. Many coworkers were very talented, highly motivated, and good to work with. The work was interesting and challenging.
cons: They practice what I call "surgical layoffs", where they target specific individuals, many of whom are very long term and productive, and begin a long, and tortured process of systematiclly documenting their "suddenly" declining performance, to the point of terminations. Oddly enough, the sales and profit numbers are usually down, and the impacted employees are typically older workers. What a coincidence. Their management team spends unbelievable amounts of time documenting this alleged decline in performance, and of course they don't have to pay severance when they let someone go. This has gone on for years!

headline: Great company!
pros: Nice management. No micro-managing. Great PTO and Holiday!
cons: Old computers. Slow system. Need dual screens. Chairs are uncomfortable.

headline: This is an insurance company masquerading as a financial services company
pros: They do provide significant marketing assistance where if a financial advisor's marketing continues to produce revenue the pot of money continues to replenish…. no other firm does this…
cons:
This company has cobbled together it's computer systems to try to accomplish what is necessary. Very cumbersome and inefficient! Definitely not the place for someone who does SMA business. 

If you want to morph into an insurance salesman this is the place for you…. you will be supported generously and you will love to say these two words…. River   Source. 

The back office does not understand the securities industry. They can't even get cost basis right They don't understand Trusts. Death settlements are a nightmare.

headline: OK for Ameriprise as a company
pros: Smart People and very detailed focused.
cons: Everyone has worked there for over 10 years.  No new ideas.

headline: Good till now to some extent.
pros: One will get enough time to learn the new things.
cons: Lots of politics. Not so good working environment.

headline: Good work experience
pros: Flexible work hours, great support from Home Office
cons: No room to grow if you work in P2 tier, unless you become a FA or AFA

headline: Lot's of different opportunities. Many people spend their entire careers here.
pros: Great people and there are many different opportunities.
cons: No work/life balance. There is a culture of work more with fewer resources.

headline: Terrible company unless you live in India
pros: Big company name on your resume
cons: Politics!  They just let go two ~30 year veterans to Ameriprise today in the Finance dept.  Have to cut people who have been here too long and make too much and add more jobs in India.  All so the most senior leadership can continue to receive their multli million bonus.  Absolutely disgusting!  No opportunities to move around and they only promote their friends.  Hard work goes unrecognized/unrewarded.

headline: While I wasn't a fan of the franchise advisor I worked for, I found everyone at Ameriprise headquarters to be great!
pros: The people I interacted with from technology service desk and the minneapolis headquarters were always willing to help me figure out what steps I needed to take whenever I needed help.
cons: I hated the voice activated menu when I called the home office. No matter how slowly I gave an account number, or a client ID, the program always got it wrong.

headline: Series 7 home office
pros: Great place to get started. Management wants you to get many licenses.
cons: Lots of hours, so not conducive to a family life.

headline: Great Company
pros:
Great opportunities for advancement
Good benefits
Good leadership - they care about your career path and will help you get there by helping with networking, etc. 
High emphasis on performance and development planning
Great values and culture, value diversity
cons:
Because of the highly regulated industry, hard to get things done quickly or easily
Sometimes difficult to work cross-organizationally
Hard to get mind share with advisors if you aren't one of the big-time products (Insurance/annuities/funds, etc)

headline: Depends on your workers
pros: Small size and you might work on different  tasks at a same time.
cons: It has a great platform for employees to work on their daily job and do the financial planning. Those software platforms are savvy!

headline: Bureaucratic, micromanaging, dysfunctional
pros: Base pay - if you come in with a good salary from another company.
cons: In my experience, employees are not empowered to make decisions below a VP level.  Home office VPs are typically company-loyal and have not  -- nor ever will be able to -- work anywhere else. The company reorganizes frequently, eliminating roles and then making employees apply for positions that are quite similar to the job that was eliminated (not a healthy way to develop or retain talent as everyone is at risk and then competes against others).  Vacation is sub-par unless you've spent your lie there or you're a VP.

headline: Great work experience!
pros:
Great work enviromnent to workin and benfits are not too bad either.
Company is growing and expnaindg every year.
cons: Employer could add more diversity into the workforce

headline: Would not go back to work at AMP
pros: They will hire anyone off the street, so great chance to gain experience.
cons: Pay, Opportunities for growth, decisions are made based on internal politics

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Decent company for financial advisors that want to work with the average joe client.
cons: Very bureaucratic, limited resources compared to the wirehouses.

headline: I had a long and successful career at Ameriprise.
pros: There is a high concentration of dedicated and exceptional people working there.  In my experience, the company really walks the talk about work/life balance.  The financial planning benefit is a tremendous value, especially to younger employees who take advantage of it right from the start.
cons: It is in many ways a typical Fortune 500 organization.  There is too much bureaucracy, decisions often require far too long to make, and at times an excessive focus on process.

headline: Good company, good compensation and benefits; Need to change certain leaders to realize objectives C team has set.
pros: Good company, decent compensation, good benefits
cons: Certain leaders have minds made up about individuals and don't allow direct leaders assess based on performance results.

headline: An all right place to work
pros:
Work life balance
Flexibility 
Can work with nice people
cons:
Terrible benefits
Not much opportunity for career growth

pros:
Work life balance is great 
Work culture is good 
Individuals respect each other
cons: There needs to be more collaboration between India and US team. More onsite opportunities should be given and India Team should be given much more challenging work

headline: Things could be better
pros:
- very flexible with time off
- close to where I live, very nice & central location (next to everything including a great shopping center)
- nice boss
- nice working environment (I have my own space set up in a staff room, more privacy)
- nice staff
- supportive of my personal life endeavors
cons:
- terrible compensation plan (underpaid, no room for growth or improvement in my position)
- no health benefits 
- benefit plan is very weak - ie: I worked a full year part-time (30 hr/week) with no benefits at all,   only after a full year I've received an extra 5 hours/week (full-time at 35hrs/week), paid sick leave (6 days/year), 11 days of paid vacation and 6 paid holidays and a weak quarterly bonus schedule (which I constantly have to remind my boss about and it changes every quarter - unstable) 
- difficulty working for a disorganized boss who doesn't take note of me trying to organize him
- very poor communication between the 4 advisors in the office and in general (between all of the employees)
- feeling no synergy or team work in the office, everyone is working for their own best interests (no looking out for each other)

headline: My job
pros: I like the variety of tasks that are part of my job, which means it is never boring.  I like the people I work with.  The company has amazing benefits.
cons: No chance to attend advanced classes related to my job.  Everything is geared to further the education/knowledge of those on the phone, which is important because they are the front line into the company.

headline: fear of the lay-off
pros: You are paid well at this company and they are one of the top financial companies around.  The main HQ offices are in a great location, skyway access in downtown Minneapolis.
cons: They go through cycles of lay-offs, so there is always the fear of when it will hit you and your team.  There is also a lot of outsourcing.  Leadership within some groups is lacking, decisions are not always made without all accurate information being supplied, so the decisions are not always the best.  There is little accountability for poor leadership and poor work ethics; it's definitely 'who you know' vs. quality work.

headline: Senior leaders get it
pros: The majority of the senior leaders understand the space and are focused on being a better firm.  It's a finance dominated culture, which means a respectable amount of discipline.
cons:
It's a finance dominated culture, which means some investments that should be made don't happen.

Organization struggles with red tape and process... i.e. this is how we have always done it, why change.  This is slowly, slowly, slowly going away though.

headline: Educational
pros: Learned a great deal of knowledge about investing, the importance of savings and working with some fabulous people.
cons: Outsourcing of some jobs has been done too much in my opinion.

headline: Say goodbye to a career
pros: Overtime, they'll pay for your license
cons: The rest of the company sees the Advisor Center as a joke, and outside firms see it as worse. There's no opportunity to advance unless you churn accounts or want to work in service, the center isn't sustainable and management has no intention of fixing that aside from making you generate your own leads (for which you'll receive the lowest payout in the industry).

headline: Basic Brokerage Firm
pros: As a new trainee, the support provided by the company is tremendous.  They provide help from coaching and finance some events for you.
cons: Product offering is very limited.  When working with high networth clients, we weren't able to provide a wide range of products to clients/prospects.

headline: Company Environment and work culture
pros:
1) Employee friendly environment
2) Well equipped with facilities 
3) Cab ficility
cons:
1) Mobile phones not allowed
2) Some departments require extra work hours (stretching) and no over time paid for the same
3) No outings and trips!

headline: Its a learning experience and great exposure in the field of Compliance.
pros: Nice Working environment, good pay master and a growing business.
cons: lack of internal movements, rigid policies and slow HR processes

headline: Was Better Before Separating from AMEX
pros:
Good benefits
CO-WORKERS are great
Facilities are nice
GYM available
IN-HOUSE cafateria
cons:
Inconsistent management structure (VP WITH 2 DIRECT REPORTS????)
No appreciation for your contributions ... only what can you do for me next??
Ancient technology
HR protects bad and abusive managers
Easy to get "pigeonholed"

headline: Great Company - Some Bad Managers
pros:
-Great Pay
-Great Benefits
-Great Vacation 
-Great Company Ethics/Values
cons: -Some bad managers micromanage so much that it makes it next-to-impossible to get your job done

headline: Excellent Learning Opportunities
pros: Team work, suitable rewards and recognition
cons: Stretches, low compensation structure at entry level

headline: Hate to be so negative, but...
pros: It's a great place to work if you have a good relationship with your boss, and they actually pay you what you are worth. You spend a majority of the day interacting with him/her, on top of phone and face-to-face with clients. The paperwork can be overwhelming, but at least it's not the usual boring stuff like in typical office environments.
cons: Most of the advisors I've worked for really care only about their own bottom line...they tend to be extremely cheap when it comes to rewarding their employees for a job well done. My last boss depended on me for virtually everything, and even a few things that I knew were unethical. Yes, I had her back, but felt that she never had mine. It was a bitter break-up, and I know there are two sides to every story, but it was a really messed up situation...one I hope never to be in again.

headline: nice place to work at
pros: nice people, good place for young people to start career, management is supportive and patient (but I guess that depends on people).
cons: if you work in one of the financial adviser office, your life is not that exciting. very basic marketing stuff, not a lot of finance stuff

headline: Great place to work.
pros: They are fair with their payouts and are very helpful with ideas.
cons: They are an old boys club at times.

headline: Great learning experience
pros:
friendly environment
great coworkers 
flexible schedule
cons: wages, location, hours, distance, raise

headline: My Opinion
pros: Work life balance is good, leaders are reasonable, though cuts happen they see to be done with care and fairness.
cons: Sometimes larger and more complex than needed.  Funding is complex for technologies.  Need more skilled resources and working on it.

headline: good for a stop gap is all
pros: benefits and ameriprise university are good.
cons: low compensation. Lowest in the business by what i can tell

headline: A great way to learn about the responsibilities of a financial advisor
pros: It was a great work atmosphere with a focus on serving clients and managing relationships to yield positive results for the practice
cons: Disorganized office environment did not mesh well with the stringent compliance requirements sent down from the home office.

headline: A great way to learn about the responsibilities of a financial advisor
pros: It was a great work atmosphere with a focus on serving clients and managing relationships to yield positive results for the practice
cons: Disorganized office environment did not mesh well with the stringent compliance requirements sent down from the home office.

headline: Good
pros: benefits are good and they paid ok
cons: advancement may be challeging if you are not good at political games

headline: At first it was good then went down hill after outsourcing and management changes.
pros: I got a paycheck and made some good life long friends.
cons: Good ole boy company. Bad management protected by human resources.  Technology is archaic. People are rewarded by how much the leader likes you.  Outsourcing was a really bad idea. They eliminate positions once you've been there 10+ years and hire someone younger and cheaper.

headline: Excellent company for growth in practice and knowledge
pros: excellent technology, marketing, knowledge, succession support - with onpgoing support in practice needs and growth - client based support services are also excellent
cons: limited insurance and annuity options, some inconsistencies in the brokerage in that some investments are not available due to internal company arrangements

headline: Very diversified and friendly workplace atmosphere
pros: Diversified culture.  The company believes in career planning and development.
cons: Not alot of positions to move around within the company

headline: Not a Good Place for Beginners, but a Great Place for Transfers
pros: Supervision is helpful....not repressive, You manage your own business and time, payouts are excellent, management is hands-off. Other advisors are very helpful. Field technology and automation is excellent. Is everything my last firm (EDJ) was not.
cons: You are on your own getting up and running...Technical help with trading platform is sketchy, organization hierarchy is a bit nebulous

headline: Disappointed
pros:
Easy-going people
Flexible schedule
Networking opportunities
Always open to hiring new interns
cons:
Didn't learn a thing
Was stuck with grunt work (scanning, filing)
Realized a financial advisor is just a salesman

headline: Great place to work, job titles misaligned with actual duties
pros: Great communication, very empowering atmosphere
cons: There was nothing analytical in the daily responsibilities of a call center analyst.  It was essentially a customer service representative position.  Unfortunately, they have severely handicapped their ability to validate the accuracy of their workforce adherence projections, as all the call center analysts do is answer phone calls from call center representatives who need their break and work segments adjusted, by as little as three minutes.  Call center adherence metrics should be built with a certain percentage of "shrinkage" built in, as we all know that, due to the nature of call volume, no one can adhere to their schedule 100%.  Forcing the representatives to have to have their segments adjusted places undue stress on them and is a waste of everyone's time.  There was no challenge in this position.

headline: Great
pros: We have Flexible hours.  Unlimited potential.
cons: we do not have benefits for insurance or stock purchase at disount.

headline: I'm disappointed in my experience but it will depend on the firm you work for.
pros: If you can build a client base, the income potential is very high. The corporate office is generally resourceful and willing to help you solve problems.
cons: Small and family firms can be very difficult to adjust to if you're an outsider; however, it will depend on the firm.

headline: It has been a great learning experience along with meeting lots of people and I love preparing tax returns.
pros: Working At HRB, I have the chance to show my talents and experience as an associate and help others learn how to understand why it is important to save receipts and budget your wages and expenses. It is a great feeling when you make others happy and satisfied and you know you have made a new friend.
cons: The things that have room for change is the ability to work during the summer hours, advancing with higher salaries, keeping prior clients from years gone by, not having the advantage  of working all year round and having to pay for Cobra during the off time outside of the season.

headline: hard
pros: unlimited opportunity to grow your own practice
cons: very hard to build client base

headline: Very Top Heavy
pros:
Excellent benefits package
good interal training programs
cons:
very top heavy and the actual peopl who do the work are very limited in resources
mgmt needs to stay away from certain decision makings and leave it to the project mgrs

headline: I learned a great deal at Ameriprise but the learning came through self motivation rather than senior guidance.
pros: Ameriprise is a leading financial planning company that has recently increased its advertising. A financial advisor should be able to leverage this when looking for new clients.
cons: The company as a whole is very discombobulated. Back office and financial advisors are rarely on the same pages as each other. I witnessed paperwork processes that should have taken no more than a few days last several months.

headline: Growing company, changes fast
pros: Opportunities, benefits, work life balance
cons: Old technology, limited access to managers

headline: Not the best place to start
pros: Technology is great. Some of the best systems available.
cons: The offices are disappearing. They used to hire almost anyone and then see who shakes out. No real advice or support from management. Managers are inexperienced as well.

headline: Could have been a great company
pros:
Good regional brand recognition
Small office feel
cons: The only con about HRBFA is that it no longer exist

headline: mixed experience
pros: lots of vacation time.  Flexible work schedule in some departments
cons: Extremely hierarchical.  Very difficult to grow professionally

headline: Intense, cutt-throat.
pros: No ceiling on your income.  If you're motivated and you can handle the heat, plenty of opportunity to make a very good living.
cons: What have you done for me lately, mentality.  You can knock it out of the ball park for three straight quarters, have one bad quarter and you're constantly reminded of how you're not achieving.

headline: Company has a lot going for it but lives in a straight jacket
author_position: Manager In Corporate Line of Business
pros: Ameriprise is very "well-run". Focus on quality work and the customer are more than just lip service
cons:
Compensation structure is bad. Zero transparency to wages when almost all professional "individual-contributors" are in the same job band.

Too much work and little reward
